   159‚Üíconst approxRe = /\b(about|around|roughly|nearly|approx(?:\.|imately)?|~)\b/gi;
   160‚Üíconst metricRe = /(\$[0-9][0-9.,]*(?:\s?[KMB])?\+?|\b[0-9][0-9.,]*\s?%|\b[0-9]+\+|\b[0-9][0-9.,]*\s?[x√ó]\b)/gi;
   161‚Üí
   162‚Üífunction scanSecrets(text: string): Finding {
   163‚Üí  const hits: string[] = [];
   164‚Üí  for (const p of secretPatterns) {
   165‚Üí    const m = text.match(p.re);
   166‚Üí    if (m && m.length) hits.push(`${p.name}: ${m.slice(0, 3).join(', ')}${m.length > 3 ? '‚Ä¶' : ''}`);
   167‚Üí  }
   168‚Üí  return hits.length
   169‚Üí    ? { id: 'RT-SEC-SECRETS', title: 'Secrets / tokens accidentally committed', severity: 'FAIL', details: hits }
   170‚Üí    : { id: 'RT-SEC-SECRETS', title: 'Secrets / tokens accidentally committed', severity: 'PASS' };
   171‚Üí}
   172‚Üí
   173‚Üífunction scanConfidential(text: string): Finding {
   174‚Üí  const m = text.match(confidentialRe);
   175‚Üí  return m && m.length
   176‚Üí    ? { id: 'RT-SEC-CONFIDENTIAL', title: 'Confidential / NDA language present', severity: 'FAIL', details: unique(m).slice(0, 10) }
   177‚Üí    : { id: 'RT-SEC-CONFIDENTIAL', title: 'Confidential / NDA language present', severity: 'PASS' };
   178‚Üí}
   179‚Üí
   180‚Üífunction scanSycophancy(text: string): Finding {
   181‚Üí  const m = text.match(sycophancyRe);
   182‚Üí  return m && m.length
   183‚Üí    ? { id: 'RT-TONE-SYCOPHANCY', title: 'Sycophancy / empty praise', severity: 'WARN', details: unique(m).slice(0, 10) }
   184‚Üí    : { id: 'RT-TONE-SYCOPHANCY', title: 'Sycophancy / empty praise', severity: 'PASS' };
   185‚Üí}
   186‚Üí
   187‚Üífunction scanInjection(jd: string): Finding {
   188‚Üí  if (!jd) return { id: 'RT-INPUT-INJECTION', title: 'Prompt injection patterns in job description', severity: 'PASS' };
   189‚Üí  const m = jd.match(injectionRe);
   190‚Üí  return m && m.length
   191‚Üí    ? { id: 'RT-INPUT-INJECTION', title: 'Prompt injection patterns in job description', severity: 'WARN', details: unique(m).slice(0, 10) }
   192‚Üí    : { id: 'RT-INPUT-INJECTION', title: 'Prompt injection patterns in job description', severity: 'PASS' };
   193‚Üí}
   194‚Üí
   195‚Üífunction scanApproxNearMetrics(text: string): Finding {
   196‚Üí  // Rough heuristic: if a sentence contains both approx word and metric token -> warn.
   197‚Üí  const normalized = text.replace(/\s+/g, ' ').trim();
   198‚Üí  const sentences = normalized.split(/(?:\.\s+|\?\s+|!\s+|\n+)/).map(s => s.trim()).filter(Boolean);
   199‚Üí
   200‚Üí  const flagged: string[] = [];
   201‚Üí  for (const s of sentences) {
   202‚Üí    if (approxRe.test(s) && metricRe.test(s)) {
   203‚Üí      flagged.push(s.length > 160 ? s.slice(0, 157) + '‚Ä¶' : s);
   204‚Üí    }
   205‚Üí    // reset regex state (global regex)
   206‚Üí    approxRe.lastIndex = 0;
   207‚Üí    metricRe.lastIndex = 0;
   208‚Üí  }
   209‚Üí
   210‚Üí  return flagged.length
   211‚Üí    ? { id: 'RT-ACC-INFLATION', title: 'Approximation language near metrics (inflation risk)', severity: 'WARN', details: flagged.slice(0, 5) }
   212‚Üí    : { id: 'RT-ACC-INFLATION', title: 'Approximation language near metrics (inflation risk)', severity: 'PASS' };
   213‚Üí}
   214‚Üí
   215‚Üífunction scanClaimsLedger(slug: string, ledger: any | null): Finding {
   216‚Üí  if (!ledger) {
   217‚Üí    return {
   218‚Üí      id: 'RT-ACC-CLAIMS',
   219‚Üí      title: 'Claims ledger exists and is verified',
   220‚Üí      severity: 'FAIL',
   221‚Üí      details: [`Missing ledger: capstone/develop/evals/${slug}.claims.yaml`, 'Run: npm run eval:variant -- --slug ' + slug]
   222‚Üí    };
   223‚Üí  }
   224‚Üí
   225‚Üí  const claims: any[] = ledger.claims || [];
   226‚Üí  const unverified = claims.filter(c => c?.verified?.status !== 'verified');
   227‚Üí
   228‚Üí  if (unverified.length) {
   229‚Üí    return {
   230‚Üí      id: 'RT-ACC-CLAIMS',
   231‚Üí      title: 'Claims ledger exists and is verified',
   232‚Üí      severity: 'FAIL',
   233‚Üí      details: unverified.slice(0, 8).map(c => `${c.id} (${c.location})`)
   234‚Üí    };
   235‚Üí  }
   236‚Üí
   237‚Üí  return { id: 'RT-ACC-CLAIMS', title: 'Claims ledger exists and is verified', severity: 'PASS' };
   238‚Üí}
   239‚Üí
   240‚Üífunction scanPublicJobDescription(jd: string): Finding {
   241‚Üí  if (!jd) return { id: 'RT-PRIV-JD', title: 'Job description exposure risk (public JSON)', severity: 'PASS' };
   242‚Üí  // Your variants are shipped client-side as JSON. Long JDs are risky to publish.
   243‚Üí  return jd.length > 1200
   244‚Üí    ? {
   245‚Üí        id: 'RT-PRIV-JD',
   246‚Üí        title: 'Job description exposure risk (public JSON)',
   247‚Üí        severity: 'WARN',
   248‚Üí        details: [
   249‚Üí          `jobDescription length is ${jd.length} characters.`,
   250‚Üí          'Consider storing only a short excerpt in variant metadata (or stripping it in build).'
   251‚Üí        ]
   252‚Üí      }
   253‚Üí    : { id: 'RT-PRIV-JD', title: 'Job description exposure risk (public JSON)', severity: 'PASS' };
   254‚Üí}
   255‚Üí
   256‚Üífunction scanCrossVariantContamination(slug: string, company: string, text: string): Finding {
   257‚Üí  const companies = listVariantCompanies();
   258‚Üí  const others = companies.filter(c => c && c.toLowerCase() !== company.toLowerCase());
   259‚Üí
   260‚Üí  const hits: string[] = [];
   261‚Üí  for (const o of others) {
   262‚Üí    const re = new RegExp(`\\b${escapeRegExp(o)}\\b`, 'i');
   263‚Üí    if (re.test(text)) hits.push(o);
   264‚Üí  }
   265‚Üí
   266‚Üí  return hits.length
   267‚Üí    ? { id: 'RT-XVAR-CONTAM', title: 'Cross-variant contamination (mentions other target companies)', severity: 'WARN', details: unique(hits) }
   268‚Üí    : { id: 'RT-XVAR-CONTAM', title: 'Cross-variant contamination (mentions other target companies)', severity: 'PASS' };
   269‚Üí}
   270‚Üí
   271‚Üífunction listVariantCompanies(): string[] {
   272‚Üí  const variantsDir = join(process.cwd(), 'content', 'variants');
   273‚Üí  if (!existsSync(variantsDir)) return [];
   274‚Üí  const slugs = readdirSync(variantsDir)
   275‚Üí    .filter(f => f.endsWith('.yaml'))
   276‚Üí    .filter(f => !f.startsWith('_'))
   277‚Üí    .map(f => f.replace(/\.yaml$/, ''));
   278‚Üí
   279‚Üí  const companies: string[] = [];
   280‚Üí  for (const slug of slugs) {
   281‚Üí    try {
   282‚Üí      const { validated } = readVariantYaml(slug);
   283‚Üí      companies.push(validated.metadata.company);
   284‚Üí    } catch {
   285‚Üí      // ignore
   286‚Üí    }
   287‚Üí  }
   288‚Üí  return unique(companies);
   289‚Üí}
   290‚Üí
   291‚Üífunction escapeRegExp(s: string): string {
   292‚Üí  return s.replace(/[.*+?^${}()|[\]\\]/g, '\\$&');
   293‚Üí}
   294‚Üí
   295‚Üífunction unique(arr: string[]): string[] {
   296‚Üí  return [...new Set(arr)];
   297‚Üí}
   298‚Üí
   299‚Üífunction severityScore(sev: Finding['severity']): number {
   300‚Üí  return sev === 'FAIL' ? 2 : sev === 'WARN' ? 1 : 0;
   301‚Üí}
   302‚Üí
   303‚Üífunction writeReport(slug: string, findings: Finding[]) {
   304‚Üí  const dir = join(process.cwd(), 'capstone', 'develop', 'redteam');
   305‚Üí  ensureDir(dir);
   306‚Üí  const path = join(dir, `${slug}.redteam.md`);
   307‚Üí
   308‚Üí  const failCount = findings.filter(f => f.severity === 'FAIL').length;
   309‚Üí  const warnCount = findings.filter(f => f.severity === 'WARN').length;
   310‚Üí
   311‚Üí  const lines: string[] = [];
   312‚Üí  lines.push(`# Red Team Report`);
   313‚Üí  lines.push('');
   314‚Üí  lines.push(`- Variant: \`${slug}\``);
   315‚Üí  lines.push(`- Generated: ${new Date().toISOString()}`);
   316‚Üí  lines.push('');
   317‚Üí  lines.push(`## Summary`);
   318‚Üí  lines.push('');
   319‚Üí  lines.push(`- FAIL: **${failCount}**`);
   320‚Üí  lines.push(`- WARN: **${warnCount}**`);
   321‚Üí  lines.push('');
   322‚Üí  lines.push(`## Checks`);
   323‚Üí  lines.push('');
   324‚Üí  lines.push(`| ID | Result | Check |`);
   325‚Üí  lines.push(`|---|---|---|`);
   326‚Üí
   327‚Üí  for (const f of findings) {
   328‚Üí    const icon = f.severity === 'PASS' ? '‚úÖ PASS' : f.severity === 'WARN' ? '‚ö†Ô∏è WARN' : '‚ùå FAIL';
   329‚Üí    lines.push(`| \`${f.id}\` | ${icon} | ${f.title} |`);
   330‚Üí  }
   331‚Üí
   332‚Üí  lines.push('');
   333‚Üí  lines.push(`## Details`);
   334‚Üí  lines.push('');
   335‚Üí  for (const f of findings.filter(x => x.details && x.details.length)) {
   336‚Üí    lines.push(`### ${f.id} ‚Äî ${f.title}`);
   337‚Üí    lines.push('');
   338‚Üí    for (const d of f.details!) lines.push(`- ${d}`);
   339‚Üí    lines.push('');
   340‚Üí  }
   341‚Üí
   342‚Üí  writeFileSync(path, lines.join('\n') + '\n', 'utf-8');
   343‚Üí  return path;
   344‚Üí}
   345‚Üí
   346‚Üífunction redteamOne(slug: string, args: Args): RedteamResult {
   347‚Üí  try {
   348‚Üí    const { validated } = readVariantYaml(slug);
   349‚Üí
   350‚Üí    const overrideTexts: string[] = [];
   351‚Üí    collectStrings(validated.overrides, overrideTexts);
   352‚Üí    const text = overrideTexts.join('\n');
   353‚Üí
   354‚Üí    const jd = validated.metadata?.jobDescription ?? '';
   355‚Üí    const ledger = loadClaimsLedger(slug);
   356‚Üí
   357‚Üí    const findings: Finding[] = [];
   358‚Üí
   359‚Üí    findings.push(scanClaimsLedger(slug, ledger));
   360‚Üí    findings.push(scanSecrets(text));
   361‚Üí    findings.push(scanConfidential(text));
   362‚Üí    findings.push(scanSycophancy(text));
   363‚Üí    findings.push(scanApproxNearMetrics(text));
   364‚Üí    findings.push(scanInjection(jd));
   365‚Üí    findings.push(scanPublicJobDescription(jd));
   366‚Üí    findings.push(scanCrossVariantContamination(slug, validated.metadata.company, text));
   367‚Üí
   368‚Üí    // Sort: FAIL first, WARN, PASS (nice report)
   369‚Üí    findings.sort((a, b) => severityScore(b.severity) - severityScore(a.severity));
   370‚Üí
   371‚Üí    const reportPath = args.noWrite ? undefined : writeReport(slug, findings);
   372‚Üí
   373‚Üí    const fails = findings.filter(f => f.severity === 'FAIL');
   374‚Üí    const warns = findings.filter(f => f.severity === 'WARN');
   375‚Üí    const shouldFail = fails.length > 0 || (args.strict && warns.length > 0);
   376‚Üí
   377‚Üí    return {
   378‚Üí      slug,
   379‚Üí      status: shouldFail ? 'fail' : warns.length > 0 ? 'warn' : 'pass',
   380‚Üí      fails: fails.length,
   381‚Üí      warns: warns.length,
   382‚Üí      reportPath,
   383‚Üí      findings: args.json ? findings : undefined
   384‚Üí    };
   385‚Üí  } catch (err) {
   386‚Üí    return {
   387‚Üí      slug,
   388‚Üí      status: 'error',
   389‚Üí      fails: 0,
   390‚Üí      warns: 0,
   391‚Üí      message: err instanceof Error ? err.message : String(err)
   392‚Üí    };
   393‚Üí  }
   394‚Üí}
   395‚Üí
   396‚Üíasync function main() {
   397‚Üí  const args = parseArgs();
   398‚Üí  const slugs = args.all ? listVariantSlugs() : [args.slug!];
   399‚Üí
   400‚Üí  // JSON output mode - minimal, machine-readable
   401‚Üí  if (args.json) {
   402‚Üí    if (slugs.length === 0) {
   403‚Üí      console.log(JSON.stringify({ mode: args.check ? 'check' : 'redteam', results: [], errors: [] }));
   404‚Üí      process.exit(0);
   405‚Üí    }
   406‚Üí
   407‚Üí    const results = slugs.map(slug => redteamOne(slug, args));
   408‚Üí    const output = {
   409‚Üí      mode: args.check ? 'check' : 'redteam',
   410‚Üí      strict: args.strict,
   411‚Üí      results: results.filter(r => r.status !== 'error'),
   412‚Üí      errors: results.filter(r => r.status === 'error')
   413‚Üí    };
   414‚Üí
   415‚Üí    console.log(JSON.stringify(output, null, 2));
   416‚Üí    const hasFailures = results.some(r => r.status === 'fail' || r.status === 'error');
   417‚Üí    process.exit(hasFailures ? 1 : 0);
   418‚Üí  }
   419‚Üí
   420‚Üí  // Interactive output
   421‚Üí  if (!args.quiet) {
   422‚Üí    console.log(HEADER_COMPACT);
   423‚Üí    console.log();
   424‚Üí  }
   425‚Üí
   426‚Üí  if (slugs.length === 0) {
   427‚Üí    if (!args.quiet) {
   428‚Üí      console.log(theme.muted('No variants found. Nothing to red-team.'));
   429‚Üí    }
   430‚Üí    process.exit(0);
   431‚Üí  }
   432‚Üí
   433‚Üí  const spinner = ora({
   434‚Üí    text: args.check ? 'Checking variants...' : 'Running red team scans...',
   435‚Üí    color: 'yellow'
   436‚Üí  }).start();
   437‚Üí
   438‚Üí  const results: RedteamResult[] = [];
   439‚Üí
   440‚Üí  for (const slug of slugs) {
   441‚Üí    const result = redteamOne(slug, args);
   442‚Üí    results.push(result);
   443‚Üí  }
   444‚Üí
   445‚Üí  spinner.stop();
   446‚Üí
   447‚Üí  // Display results
   448‚Üí  const passed = results.filter(r => r.status === 'pass');
   449‚Üí  const warned = results.filter(r => r.status === 'warn');
   450‚Üí  const failed = results.filter(r => r.status === 'fail');
   451‚Üí  const errors = results.filter(r => r.status === 'error');
   452‚Üí
   453‚Üí  if (!args.quiet) {
   454‚Üí    console.log(theme.bold(args.check ? 'Red Team Check' : 'Red Team Scan'));
   455‚Üí    console.log(theme.muted(`${results.length} variant(s)`));
   456‚Üí    console.log();
   457‚Üí
   458‚Üí    for (const r of results) {
   459‚Üí      if (r.status === 'error') {
   460‚Üí        console.log(`${theme.icons.error} ${r.slug} ${theme.error('error')}`);
   461‚Üí        if (r.message) console.log(theme.muted(`  ${r.message}`));
   462‚Üí      } else if (r.status === 'fail') {
   463‚Üí        console.log(`${theme.icons.error} ${r.slug} ${theme.error(`${r.fails} FAIL`)} ${theme.warning(`${r.warns} WARN`)}`);
   464‚Üí        if (r.reportPath) console.log(theme.muted(`  ${r.reportPath}`));
   465‚Üí      } else if (r.status === 'warn') {
   466‚Üí        console.log(`${theme.icons.warning} ${r.slug} ${theme.warning(`${r.warns} WARN`)}`);
   467‚Üí        if (r.reportPath) console.log(theme.muted(`  ${r.reportPath}`));
   468‚Üí      } else {
   469‚Üí        console.log(`${theme.icons.success} ${r.slug} ${theme.success('passed')}`);
   470‚Üí      }
   471‚Üí    }
   472‚Üí
   473‚Üí    console.log();
   474‚Üí    console.log(
   475‚Üí      theme.muted('Summary:'),
   476‚Üí      `${passed.length} passed,`,
   477‚Üí      `${warned.length} warnings,`,
   478‚Üí      `${failed.length + errors.length} failed`
   479‚Üí    );
   480‚Üí  }
   481‚Üí
   482‚Üí  if (failed.length > 0 || errors.length > 0) {
   483‚Üí    process.exit(1);
   484‚Üí  }
   485‚Üí
   486‚Üí  process.exit(0);
   487‚Üí}
   488‚Üí
   489‚Üímain().catch((err) => {
   490‚Üí  console.error(`${theme.icons.error} ${theme.error('Fatal:')} ${err instanceof Error ? err.message : String(err)}`);
   491‚Üí  process.exit(1);
   492‚Üí});

     2‚Üí
     3‚Üí## When to Use This Skill
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíActivate when the user:
     6‚Üí- Says "reorient", "am I drifting?", "reality check", or "productive procrastination"

    14‚Üí## The Framework
    15‚Üí
    16‚Üí### Step 1: Ask Three Questions
    17‚Üí

    20‚Üí```

    28‚Üí### Step 2: Identify the Gap

    30‚ÜíAfter they answer, assess:
    31‚Üí
    32‚Üí| Signal | Likely Status |
    33‚Üí|--------|---------------|
    34‚Üí| Clear goal + output matches | On track ‚Äî keep going |
    35‚Üí| Clear goal + output is tangential | Drifting ‚Äî redirect needed |
    36‚Üí| Vague goal + lots of "exploration" | Productive procrastination |
    37‚Üí| Building tools to build tools | Deep drift ‚Äî hard redirect |
    38‚Üí
    39‚Üí### Step 3: Give the Honest Feedback
    40‚Üí
    41‚Üí**If on track**: Acknowledge briefly and get out of the way.
    42‚Üí
    43‚Üí**If drifting**, use this format:
    44‚Üí
    45‚Üí```

    47‚Üí
    48‚ÜíWhat you're doing: [describe the activity]
    49‚ÜíWhat it feels like: [productive/interesting/important]
    50‚ÜíWhat it actually is: [avoiding the harder thing/premature optimization/scope creep]
    51‚Üí
    52‚ÜíThe thing you're avoiding is probably: [name it]
    53‚Üí```
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí### Step 4: Redirect with One Action

    59‚Üí```

    63‚ÜíSwitch now. The thing you're working on will still be there.
    64‚Üí```
    65‚Üí
    66‚Üí---
    67‚Üí
    68‚Üí## ADHD-Specific Guidance
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí### Recognize the Patterns
    71‚Üí
    72‚Üí| Pattern | What It Looks Like | The Truth |
    73‚Üí|---------|-------------------|-----------|
    74‚Üí| **Tooling Rabbit Hole** | "I'll build a CLI to automate this" | The manual way takes 5 minutes |
    75‚Üí| **Perfect Setup** | "Let me organize everything first" | You're avoiding starting |
    76‚Üí| **Research Loop** | "I need to understand X before Y" | You already know enough |
    77‚Üí| **Scope Creep** | "While I'm here, I should also..." | Finish the first thing |
    78‚Üí| **Yak Shaving** | 4 levels deep in dependencies | Original task forgotten |
    79‚Üí
    80‚Üí### The Questions That Cut Through
    81‚Üí
    82‚Üí- "If you had to ship something in 30 minutes, what would it be?"
    83‚Üí- "What's the ONE thing that moves you closer to employed?"
    84‚Üí- "Is this thing you're building something a recruiter will ever see?"
    85‚Üí- "Are you building or are you preparing to build?"
    86‚Üí
    87‚Üí### Time-Boxing Reality
    88‚Üí
    89‚Üí```
    90‚ÜíIf the task feels like it needs "a few hours" ‚Üí It's probably scope creep
    91‚ÜíIf you've been "almost done" for 30+ minutes ‚Üí You're stuck, not finishing
    92‚ÜíIf you keep finding "one more thing" ‚Üí You're avoiding completion
    93‚Üí```
    94‚Üí
    95‚Üí---
    96‚Üí
    97‚Üí## Hard Truths to Deploy When Needed
    98‚Üí
    99‚ÜíUse these when gentle redirection isn't working:
   100‚Üí
   101‚Üí> "The portfolio doesn't need to be perfect. It needs to exist and be seen."
   102‚Üí
   103‚Üí> "No one will hire you because your internal tooling is elegant."
   104‚Üí
   105‚Üí> "Shipping something imperfect beats perfecting something unshipped."
   106‚Üí
   107‚Üí> "The best variant is the one you actually send to a real job posting."
   108‚Üí
   109‚Üí> "You're not procrastinating ‚Äî you're protecting yourself from rejection by never finishing."
   110‚Üí
   111‚Üí> "The CLI works. The pipeline works. What doesn't exist is a submitted application."
   112‚Üí
   113‚Üí---
   114‚Üí
   115‚Üí## Output Format
   116‚Üí
   117‚ÜíKeep it SHORT. ADHD brains bounce off walls of text.
   118‚Üí
   119‚Üí```
   120‚Üí## Reality Check
   121‚Üí
   122‚Üí**Goal**: [their stated goal]
   123‚Üí**Session intent**: [what they meant to do]
   124‚Üí**Actual output**: [what they produced]
   125‚Üí
   126‚Üí**Verdict**: [On track / Drifting / Procrastinating]
   127‚Üí
   128‚Üí[If drifting: 2-3 sentences max explaining the gap]
   129‚Üí
   130‚Üí**Do this now**: [ONE action]
   131‚Üí```
   132‚Üí
   133‚Üí---
   134‚Üí
   135‚Üí## Context Files to Reference
   136‚Üí
   137‚Üí| File | Why |
   138‚Üí|------|-----|
   139‚Üí| `context/PROJECT_STATE.md` | Current priorities and blockers |
   140‚Üí| Part II | Priority Action Plan ‚Äî what actually matters |
   141‚Üí| Part VI | Session Log ‚Äî what was supposed to happen |
   142‚Üí
   143‚Üí---
   144‚Üí
   145‚Üí## The Meta-Rule
   146‚Üí
   147‚ÜíIf the user is asking for a reality check, they probably already know they're drifting. The skill's job is to:
   148‚Üí
   149‚Üí1. Confirm the suspicion without judgment
   150‚Üí2. Name the avoidance behavior specifically
   151‚Üí3. Give ONE action to switch context
   152‚Üí4. Get out of the way
   153‚Üí
   154‚ÜíDon't lecture. Don't list 10 things. Don't be gentle to the point of enabling.
   155‚Üí
   156‚ÜíBe the friend who says "dude, you're doing it again" ‚Äî not the friend who says "that sounds really interesting, tell me more."
   157‚Üí

    16‚Üí
    17‚Üíexport function App() {

    20‚Üí

    60‚Üí

    83‚Üí      )}
    84‚Üí
    85‚Üí      {screen.type === 'issues' && (

    89‚Üí        />
    90‚Üí      )}
    91‚Üí
    92‚Üí      {screen.type === 'running' && (

     5‚Üí
     6‚Üí# Dmitrii's Writing Style
     7‚Üí
     8‚Üí## When Claude MUST Use This Skill
     9‚Üí
    10‚Üí**Always invoke this skill when:**
    11‚Üí- Creating case studies or portfolio content
    12‚Üí- Writing blog posts or articles
    13‚Üí- Generating any mid-to-long form content (500+ words)
    14‚Üí- Drafting proposals, PRDs, or specifications
    15‚Üí- Composing emails or professional correspondence

    17‚Üí
    18‚ÜíThis skill is mandatory for content creation tasks‚Äînot optional.
    19‚Üí
    20‚Üí## Core Voice Characteristics
    21‚Üí
    22‚Üí**Direct and Action-Oriented**: Get to the point. Lead with the substance. Dmitrii values clarity over elaborate setups.
    23‚Üí
    24‚Üí**Warm but Professional**: Friendly tone without being informal. Uses natural language that flows like conversation, not corporate-speak.
    25‚Üí
    26‚Üí**Intellectually Curious**: Willing to probe deeper, ask "why," and challenge surface-level answers. Not afraid to admit uncertainty ("it feels that this is a bit over my head").
    27‚Üí
    28‚Üí**Practical Problem-Solver**: Always oriented toward what can be built, shipped, or acted upon.
    29‚Üí
    30‚Üí## Formatting Preferences
    31‚Üí
    32‚Üí### Anti-Patterns (Avoid)
    33‚Üí- Bullet points in emails or conversational contexts
    34‚Üí- Excessive bold/headers in short communications
    35‚Üí- Numbered lists unless truly sequential steps
    36‚Üí- HTML tags in copy-paste contexts (no `<br>`, etc.)
    37‚Üí- Robotic or overly formal phrasing
    38‚Üí- Generic corporate language
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí### Preferred Patterns
    41‚Üí- **Flowing prose** in emails and messages‚Äîideas connected with natural transitions
    42‚Üí- **Tables** for structured comparisons in documents (pricing, features, deliverables)
    43‚Üí- **Clear hierarchy** in technical docs, but minimal in casual communication
    44‚Üí- **One request per sentence** in emails‚Äîcompound requests broken naturally
    45‚Üí
    46‚Üí### When Structure IS Appropriate
    47‚Üí- PRDs and specifications (MoSCoW tables, JTBD frameworks)
    48‚Üí- Technical documentation (synopses, arguments, examples)
    49‚Üí- Proposals with clear deliverables and pricing
    50‚Üí- Research prompts with explicit constraints
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí## Writing by Context
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí### Emails & Messages
    55‚Üí- Single flowing paragraph for simple requests
    56‚Üí- No bullet points unless truly listing items (shopping list, etc.)
    57‚Üí- Warm opening without being effusive ("Hi [Name]," not "Dear Esteemed...")
    58‚Üí- Close with clear next step
    59‚Üí- If multiple points, weave them into prose
    60‚Üí
    61‚Üí**Example transformation:**
    62‚Üí```
    63‚ÜíBad:  Please:
    64‚Üí      1. Update the system
    65‚Üí      2. Forward to Mike
    66‚Üí      3. Let me know if questions
    67‚Üí
    68‚ÜíGood: Could you please update the system with the attached and forward it to Mike? Let me know if you have any questions.
    69‚Üí```
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí### Proposals & Business Documents
    72‚Üí- Lead with clear objective
    73‚Üí- Deliverables in tables or structured sections
    74‚Üí- Pricing direct and unambiguous
    75‚Üí- Next steps as concrete actions
    76‚Üí- Professional but not stiff
    77‚Üí
    78‚Üí### PRDs & Technical Specifications
    79‚Üí- Use frameworks when appropriate (MoSCoW, JTBD, user stories)
    80‚Üí- Clear sections with logical hierarchy
    81‚Üí- Tables for prioritization matrices
    82‚Üí- Explicit scope boundaries ("Won't" items)
    83‚Üí- Technical depth where warranted
    84‚Üí
    85‚Üí### Research Prompts & Instructions
    86‚Üí- Explicit scope constraints (geography, timeframe, audience)
    87‚Üí- Structured output format requirements
    88‚Üí- Clear evaluation criteria
    89‚Üí- Instruction to "not soften conclusions"
    90‚Üí- Prefer truth over excitement
    91‚Üí
    92‚Üí### Reflective & Philosophical Writing
    93‚Üí- Deep engagement without pretension
    94‚Üí- Probing questions to push past surface answers
    95‚Üí- Comfort with uncertainty and ambiguity
    96‚Üí- Uses analogies and thought experiments naturally
    97‚Üí- Willing to sit with paradox
    98‚Üí
    99‚Üí## Vocabulary & Phrasing
   100‚Üí
   101‚Üí### Prefer
   102‚Üí- "scope out" over "define"
   103‚Üí- "crisp and clear" over "concise"
   104‚Üí- "flows well" over "is readable"
   105‚Üí- "makes sense" over "is logical"
   106‚Üí- "up my alley" over "aligned with my interests"
   107‚Üí- "crack [a problem]" over "solve"
   108‚Üí- Active voice throughout
   109‚Üí
   110‚Üí### Avoid
   111‚Üí- Jargon for its own sake
   112‚Üí- Hedging language when confidence is warranted
   113‚Üí- Apologetic qualifiers ("just," "maybe," "I think perhaps...")
   114‚Üí- Filler phrases ("In order to," "It should be noted that...")
   115‚Üí
   116‚Üí## Domain Voice
   117‚Üí
   118‚ÜíDmitrii operates at the intersection of:
   119‚Üí- **Web3/Blockchain**: Comfortable with protocol terminology, tokenomics, on-chain concepts
   120‚Üí- **Product Management**: JTBD, MoSCoW, user stories, roadmaps

   122‚Üí- **AI/Agents**: Agent identity, attestation, autonomy
   123‚Üí
   124‚ÜíWhen writing in these domains, use precise terminology without over-explaining basics‚Äîassume technical competence in the reader.
   125‚Üí
   126‚Üí## Quality Checks
   127‚Üí
   128‚ÜíBefore finalizing any writing, verify:

   132‚Üí4. Is the ask/conclusion clear?
   133‚Üí5. Would Dmitrii actually say this out loud?

    20‚Üí## Execution Steps

   266‚Üí## Data Extraction Patterns
   267‚Üí
   268‚Üí### From LinkedIn CSV
   269‚Üí
   270‚Üí| LinkedIn Column | Maps To |
   271‚Üí|-----------------|---------|
   272‚Üí| Company Name | `experience.company` |
   273‚Üí| Title | `experience.role` |
   274‚Üí| Started On / Finished On | `experience.period` |
   275‚Üí| Location | `experience.location` |
   276‚Üí| Description | Parse for `highlights` |
   277‚Üí
   278‚Üí### From Resume Text
   279‚Üí

     5‚Üí
     6‚Üí# Universal CV Data Ingestion & Organization
     7‚Üí
     8‚ÜíTransforms unstructured career data into the portfolio's content structure, ready for variant generation and "hired-on-sight" presentation.
     9‚Üí
    10‚Üí## Input Directory
    11‚Üí
    12‚Üí**Drop all source files in `source-data/`** ‚Äî this directory is gitignored.
    13‚Üí
    14‚Üí```
    15‚Üísource-data/
    16‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ obsidian-vault/       # Obsidian folders with .md files
    17‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ linkedin-export.csv   # CSV exports
    18‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ resume.pdf            # Resumes
    19‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ gemini-review.md      # AI summaries (processed first)
    20‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ archive.zip           # Bulk exports
    21‚Üí```
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí## Target Output Structure
    24‚Üí
    25‚ÜíAll output goes to the existing `content/` directory:
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí```
    28‚Üícontent/
    29‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ profile.yaml              # Identity, hero, about, stats
    30‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ experience/index.yaml     # Work history with rich details
    31‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ case-studies/*.md         # Project deep-dives (frontmatter + markdown)
    32‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ testimonials/index.yaml   # Social proof quotes
    33‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ certifications/index.yaml # Certs and credentials
    34‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ passion-projects/index.yaml
    35‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ skills/index.yaml         # Technical & domain skills
    36‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ variants/                 # Job-specific personalizations
    37‚Üí```
    38‚Üí
    39‚Üí## Supported Input Formats
    40‚Üí
    41‚Üí### Obsidian Vault (.md files)
    42‚Üí- Daily notes, project notes, work journals
    43‚Üí- YAML frontmatter with metadata
    44‚Üí- Tags, links, dataview syntax
    45‚Üí- Nested folder structures
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí### CSV Files
    48‚Üí- LinkedIn exports
    49‚Üí- Spreadsheet data (experience, skills, projects)
    50‚Üí- Any structured tabular career data
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí### Zip Archives
    53‚Üí- Mixed content (CSV, text, images, videos)
    54‚Üí- Bulk exports from tools
    55‚Üí- Compressed vault backups
    56‚Üí
    57‚Üí### Text Files
    58‚Üí- Resume text dumps
    59‚Üí- Job descriptions
    60‚Üí- Performance reviews
    61‚Üí- Testimonial snippets
    62‚Üí
    63‚Üí### Images & Media
    64‚Üí- Screenshots of achievements
    65‚Üí- Certificates
    66‚Üí- Project visuals
    67‚Üí- Linked for case studies
    68‚Üí
    69‚Üí---
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí## Processing Workflow
    72‚Üí
    73‚Üí### Phase 0: Schema Understanding (MANDATORY FIRST STEP)
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí**Objective**: Read and internalize the actual Zod schemas before writing ANY content.
    76‚Üí
    77‚Üí**CRITICAL**: This step MUST be completed before any file writes. Schema mismatches were the #1 source of validation errors in past runs.
    78‚Üí
    79‚Üí```bash
    80‚Üí# Always read the schema file first
    81‚ÜíRead src/lib/schemas.ts
    82‚Üí```
    83‚Üí
    84‚Üí**Key Schema Constraints to Verify**:
    85‚Üí
    86‚Üí| Content Type | Field | Constraint |
    87‚Üí|-------------|-------|------------|
    88‚Üí| Skills | `skills` | `z.array(z.string())` ‚Äî simple strings only, NOT objects |
    89‚Üí| Case Study Media | `type` | `z.enum(['blog', 'twitter', 'linkedin', 'video', 'article', 'slides'])` |
    90‚Üí| Testimonial | `featured` | `z.boolean()` ‚Äî required, not optional |
    91‚Üí| Experience | `highlights` | `z.array(z.string())` ‚Äî simple strings only |
    92‚Üí| Case Study CTA | `action` | `z.enum(['contact', 'calendly', 'linkedin'])` ‚Äî only these 3 values |
    93‚Üí
    94‚Üí**Before writing any file, confirm**:
    95‚Üí1. ‚úÖ Field types match schema exactly (string vs object vs array)
    96‚Üí2. ‚úÖ Enum values are from the allowed set
    97‚Üí3. ‚úÖ Required fields are present
    98‚Üí4. ‚úÖ Optional fields use correct null/undefined handling
    99‚Üí
   100‚Üí---
   101‚Üí
   102‚Üí### Phase 1: Data Discovery & Inventory
   103‚Üí
   104‚Üí**Objective**: Map all source files before processing.
   105‚Üí
   106‚Üí#### Step 1a: Check for Existing AI Summaries (HIGH PRIORITY)
   107‚Üí
   108‚Üí**Before parsing raw files**, look for existing AI-generated summaries or reviews. These are often more structured and save significant parsing time.
   109‚Üí
   110‚Üí```bash
   111‚Üí# Look for AI review files
   112‚Üífind source-data/ -name "*review*" -o -name "*summary*" -o -name "*gemini*" -o -name "*claude*" -o -name "*gpt*"
   113‚Üí
   114‚Üí# Check for structured exports
   115‚Üífind source-data/ -name "*.json" -o -name "*export*"
   116‚Üí```
   117‚Üí
   118‚Üí**If found**: Use as PRIMARY source, cross-reference with raw data for verification.
   119‚Üí
   120‚Üí#### Step 1b: Inventory Raw Sources
   121‚Üí
   122‚Üí```bash
   123‚Üí# For Obsidian vault
   124‚Üífind source-data/ -name "*.md" -type f | head -50
   125‚Üí
   126‚Üí# For zip archive (extract first)
   127‚Üíunzip -l source-data/*.zip | head -50
   128‚Üí
   129‚Üí# Categorize by type
   130‚Üífind source-data/ -type f \( -name "*.md" -o -name "*.csv" -o -name "*.txt" -o -name "*.json" \)
   131‚Üí```
   132‚Üí
   133‚ÜíCreate an inventory table with confidence scores:
   134‚Üí| File | Type | Category | Priority | Confidence |
   135‚Üí|------|------|----------|----------|------------|
   136‚Üí| gemini-review.md | AI Summary | All | HIGH | ‚¨õ‚¨õ‚¨õ High |
   137‚Üí| work-history.md | Markdown | Experience | High | ‚¨õ‚¨õ‚¨ú Medium |
   138‚Üí| skills.csv | CSV | Skills | Medium | ‚¨õ‚¨õ‚¨õ High |
   139‚Üí| testimonials.txt | Text | Social Proof | High | ‚¨õ‚¨ú‚¨ú Low |
   140‚Üí
   141‚Üí### Phase 2: Experience Enrichment
   142‚Üí
   143‚ÜíFor each work role, extract/synthesize:
   144‚Üí
   145‚Üí```yaml
   146‚Üí# Target: content/experience/index.yaml
   147‚Üíjobs:
   148‚Üí  - company: "Company Name"
   149‚Üí    role: "Job Title"
   150‚Üí    period: "YYYY ‚Äì YYYY"
   151‚Üí    location: "City, State"
   152‚Üí    logo: "/images/logos/company.svg"  # Optional, nullable
   153‚Üí    url: "https://company.com"         # Company website - ALWAYS extract if available
   154‚Üí    highlights:
   155‚Üí      - "Achievement with specific metric (e.g., 15√ó revenue growth)"
   156‚Üí      - "Technical accomplishment with stack details"
   157‚Üí      - "Cross-functional impact with scope"
   158‚Üí      - "Decision/trade-off that shows judgment"
   159‚Üí      - "Scale indicator (users, transactions, team size)"
   160‚Üí    tags: ["Domain1", "Tech1", "Skill1"]
   161‚Üí```
   162‚Üí
   163‚Üí**Enrichment criteria**:
   164‚Üí- 3-4 highlights per role (focused, not exhaustive)
   165‚Üí- Specific metrics > vague claims (SMART: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant)
   166‚Üí- Technologies and methodologies named
   167‚Üí- Collaboration scope mentioned
   168‚Üí- Key decisions with trade-offs
   169‚Üí
   170‚Üí#### Product Links in Highlights (IMPORTANT)
   171‚Üí
   172‚Üí**Highlights support markdown links** ‚Äî use `[Product Name](url)` to link to shipped products, docs, or proof.
   173‚Üí
   174‚Üí```yaml
   175‚Üí# Example with inline product links
   176‚Üíhighlights:
   177‚Üí  - "Shipped [Advanced API](https://ankr.com/docs/advanced-api/) from 0‚Üí1, serving 1M+ daily requests"
   178‚Üí  - "Built [Xbox royalties blockchain](https://ey.com/case-study) achieving 99% faster processing"
   179‚Üí  - "Launched [Playground V2](https://play.flow.com/) improving developer onboarding by 60%"
   180‚Üí```
   181‚Üí
   182‚Üí**Link priority for highlights**:
   183‚Üí1. Live product/demo URLs (highest credibility)
   184‚Üí2. Official documentation
   185‚Üí3. NPM/PyPI package pages
   186‚Üí4. GitHub repos
   187‚Üí5. Case studies or press coverage
   188‚Üí
   189‚Üí**Why this matters**: Recruiters verify claims. A clickable link to a live product instantly validates the work is real.
   190‚Üí
   191‚Üí#### Link Extraction (IMPORTANT)
   192‚Üí
   193‚Üí**Always extract and verify company/project URLs** so viewers can quickly validate the work is real.
   194‚Üí
   195‚Üí**Sources for URLs**:
   196‚Üí1. Company websites mentioned in source docs
   197‚Üí2. LinkedIn company pages
   198‚Üí3. Product URLs, app store links
   199‚Üí4. GitHub repos, documentation sites
   200‚Üí5. Press releases, news articles
   201‚Üí
   202‚Üí**Link extraction process**:
   203‚Üí```bash
   204‚Üí# Search source files for URLs
   205‚Üígrep -oE 'https?://[^\s<>"]+' [SOURCE_FILES]
   206‚Üí
   207‚Üí# Common patterns to look for
   208‚Üí- "company.com", "startup.io", "project.xyz"
   209‚Üí- LinkedIn: linkedin.com/company/[name]
   210‚Üí- GitHub: github.com/[org]
   211‚Üí- Product Hunt, Crunchbase links
   212‚Üí```
   213‚Üí
   214‚Üí**Validation**:
   215‚Üí- Verify URL is still active (not 404)
   216‚Üí- Prefer official company domain over third-party
   217‚Üí- For defunct companies: use archive.org link or LinkedIn
   218‚Üí
   219‚Üí| Company Type | URL Priority |
   220‚Üí|-------------|--------------|
   221‚Üí| Active startup | Official website (e.g., mempools.com) |
   222‚Üí| Enterprise | Company careers/about page |
   223‚Üí| Acquired | Parent company or press release |
   224‚Üí| Defunct | LinkedIn or archive.org |
   225‚Üí
   226‚Üí#### Confidence Scoring for Experience Data
   227‚Üí
   228‚ÜíTrack extraction confidence for each data point:
   229‚Üí
   230‚Üí| Confidence | Criteria | Action |
   231‚Üí|------------|----------|--------|
   232‚Üí| ‚¨õ‚¨õ‚¨õ **High** | Exact quote from source, verified metric, named source | Use directly |
   233‚Üí| ‚¨õ‚¨õ‚¨ú **Medium** | Synthesized from multiple sources, approximated metric | Use with note |
   234‚Üí| ‚¨õ‚¨ú‚¨ú **Low** | Inferred, placeholder metric like "[X%]", uncertain date | Flag for user review |
   235‚Üí
   236‚Üí**Before writing experience file**:
   237‚Üí1. List all LOW confidence items for user confirmation
   238‚Üí2. Mark uncertain metrics with `[VERIFY]` prefix in draft
   239‚Üí3. Only write after user confirms or provides corrections
   240‚Üí
   241‚Üí#### Pre-Validation Check (Before Writing)
   242‚Üí
   243‚Üí```yaml
   244‚Üí# Validate structure matches schema BEFORE writing
   245‚Üí# ExperienceSchema expects:
   246‚Üíjobs:
   247‚Üí  - company: string      # Required
   248‚Üí    role: string         # Required
   249‚Üí    period: string       # Required: "YYYY ‚Äì YYYY" format
   250‚Üí    location: string     # Required
   251‚Üí    logo: string | null  # Optional
   252‚Üí    url: string | null   # Optional - but ALWAYS try to populate!
   253‚Üí    highlights: string[] # Required: array of STRINGS (not objects!)
   254‚Üí    tags: string[]       # Required
   255‚Üí```
   256‚Üí
   257‚Üí### Phase 3: Case Study Mining
   258‚Üí
   259‚ÜíIdentify projects with case study potential:
   260‚Üí
   261‚Üí**Criteria**:
   262‚Üí- Clear problem ‚Üí approach ‚Üí result arc
   263‚Üí- Quantifiable impact (revenue, users, time saved)
   264‚Üí- Decision points with reasoning
   265‚Üí- Lessons learned (what worked, what didn't)
   266‚Üí
   267‚Üí```yaml
   268‚Üí# Target: content/case-studies/NN-slug.md frontmatter
   269‚Üí---
   270‚Üíid: [next_available_number]
   271‚Üíslug: project-slug
   272‚Üítitle: "Project Title"
   273‚Üícompany: "Company Name"
   274‚Üíyear: "YYYY-YY"
   275‚Üítags: [Tag1, Tag2, Tag3]
   276‚Üíduration: "X months"
   277‚Üírole: "Your Role"
   278‚Üí
   279‚Üíhook:
   280‚Üí  headline: "One-line impact statement"
   281‚Üí  impactMetric:
   282‚Üí    value: "XX%"
   283‚Üí    label: "metric label"
   284‚Üí  subMetrics:
   285‚Üí    - value: "YY"
   286‚Üí      label: "secondary metric"
   287‚Üí  thumbnail: /images/case-study-slug.png
   288‚Üí
   289‚Üícta:
   290‚Üí  headline: "Call to action question"
   291‚Üí  subtext: "Optional elaboration"
   292‚Üí  action: calendly  # or: contact, linkedin
   293‚Üí  linkText: "Let's talk ‚Üí"
   294‚Üí---
   295‚Üí
   296‚Üí[Markdown body with: Challenge, Approach, Key Decision, Execution, Results, Learnings]
   297‚Üí```
   298‚Üí
   299‚Üí### Phase 4: Testimonial Extraction
   300‚Üí
   301‚Üí#### Distinguishing Personal vs Project Testimonials (CRITICAL)
   302‚Üí
   303‚Üí**Personal testimonials** (USE these):
   304‚Üí- About the individual: "Working with [Name]...", "[Name] is exceptional at..."
   305‚Üí- Collaboration focused: "...a pleasure to work with", "...always delivered"
   306‚Üí- Skill endorsements: "...best product manager I've worked with"
   307‚Üí- Growth observations: "...grew from... to..."
   308‚Üí
   309‚Üí**Project testimonials** (DO NOT use as personal):
   310‚Üí- About the project/product: "The blockchain solution transformed..."
   311‚Üí- Company endorsements: "Microsoft's approach to..."
   312‚Üí- Generic team praise: "The team delivered..."
   313‚Üí
   314‚Üí#### Detection Heuristics
   315‚Üí
   316‚Üí**High-confidence personal testimonial signals**:
   317‚Üí```
   318‚Üí‚úÖ Contains person's name + positive verb: "[Name] led", "[Name] designed"
   319‚Üí‚úÖ Uses "I" + relationship: "I worked with", "I hired", "I managed"
   320‚Üí‚úÖ Personal qualities: "collaborative", "thoughtful", "proactive"
   321‚Üí‚úÖ Recommendation language: "I recommend", "would hire again"
   322‚Üí‚úÖ Source: LinkedIn recommendation, performance review
   323‚Üí```
   324‚Üí
   325‚Üí**Low-confidence / Project quote signals**:
   326‚Üí```
   327‚Üí‚ö†Ô∏è No personal name mentioned
   328‚Üí‚ö†Ô∏è Focuses on deliverable, not person
   329‚Üí‚ö†Ô∏è Source: press release, case study, marketing material
   330‚Üí‚ö†Ô∏è Generic praise: "great work", "successful project"
   331‚Üí```
   332‚Üí
   333‚Üí#### Search Patterns for Testimonials
   334‚Üí
   335‚Üí```bash
   336‚Üí# Phrases indicating personal testimonials
   337‚Üígrep -i "working with \[name\]" [SOURCE]
   338‚Üígrep -i "I recommend" [SOURCE]
   339‚Üígrep -i "pleasure to work" [SOURCE]
   340‚Üígrep -i "\[name\] is" [SOURCE]
   341‚Üígrep -i "one of the best" [SOURCE]
   342‚Üí
   343‚Üí# LinkedIn recommendation patterns
   344‚Üígrep -i "I had the opportunity" [SOURCE]
   345‚Üígrep -i "I've had the pleasure" [SOURCE]
   346‚Üí```
   347‚Üí
   348‚Üí#### Testimonial Quality Checklist
   349‚Üí
   350‚ÜíBefore including a testimonial:
   351‚Üí- [ ] Is it about the PERSON, not just the project?
   352‚Üí- [ ] Does it include specific details (not generic praise)?
   353‚Üí- [ ] Can the source be verified (LinkedIn, named author)?
   354‚Üí- [ ] Is the author's relationship clear (manager, peer, report)?
   355‚Üí
   356‚Üí```yaml
   357‚Üí# Target: content/testimonials/index.yaml
   358‚Üítestimonials:
   359‚Üí  - quote: >
   360‚Üí      Full testimonial text with specific details about
   361‚Üí      collaboration, impact, or skills demonstrated.
   362‚Üí    author: "Full Name"  # Or "Engineering Lead" if anonymized
   363‚Üí    initials: "FN"
   364‚Üí    role: "Their Role"
   365‚Üí    company: "Company Name"
   366‚Üí    avatar: null  # Or path to image
   367‚Üí    featured: true  # Required boolean - for prominent display
   368‚Üí```
   369‚Üí
   370‚Üí#### Gap Handling
   371‚Üí
   372‚ÜíIf no valid personal testimonials found:
   373‚Üí1. **Flag as HIGH priority gap** in gap analysis
   374‚Üí2. Suggest manual follow-up actions:
   375‚Üí   - Export LinkedIn recommendations
   376‚Üí   - Request recommendations from past colleagues
   377‚Üí   - Check old emails for praise snippets
   378‚Üí3. **DO NOT fabricate** or use project quotes as personal testimonials
   379‚Üí
   380‚Üí### Phase 5: Skills Taxonomy
   381‚Üí
   382‚Üí#### CRITICAL: Schema Constraint
   383‚Üí
   384‚Üí**The skills schema expects SIMPLE STRINGS, not objects!**
   385‚Üí
   386‚Üí```yaml
   387‚Üí# ‚ùå WRONG - This will fail validation
   388‚Üícategories:
   389‚Üí  - name: "Technical Leadership"
   390‚Üí    skills:
   391‚Üí      - name: "Platform Architecture"
   392‚Üí        level: "expert"
   393‚Üí        evidence: "..."
   394‚Üí
   395‚Üí# ‚úÖ CORRECT - Simple string array
   396‚Üícategories:
   397‚Üí  - name: "Technical Leadership"
   398‚Üí    skills:
   399‚Üí      - "Platform Architecture"
   400‚Üí      - "API Design"
   401‚Üí      - "System Integration"
   402‚Üí```
   403‚Üí
   404‚Üí#### Preserving Evidence (Workaround)
   405‚Üí
   406‚ÜíSince the schema doesn't support evidence fields, preserve context using YAML comments:
   407‚Üí
   408‚Üí```yaml
   409‚Üí# Target: content/skills/index.yaml
   410‚Üícategories:
   411‚Üí  - name: "Technical Leadership"
   412‚Üí    skills:
   413‚Üí      # Evidence: Designed multi-client validator infra at Anchorage
   414‚Üí      - "Platform Architecture"
   415‚Üí      # Evidence: Shipped Ankr Advanced APIs, 1M+ daily requests
   416‚Üí      - "API Design"
   417‚Üí
   418‚Üí  - name: "Web3 & Blockchain"
   419‚Üí    skills:
   420‚Üí      # Evidence: First smart contract at Microsoft (2016)
   421‚Üí      - "Ethereum"
   422‚Üí      # Evidence: ETF-grade validator provisioning
   423‚Üí      - "Staking Infrastructure"
   424‚Üí```
   425‚Üí
   426‚Üí#### Pre-Validation Check
   427‚Üí
   428‚Üí```typescript
   429‚Üí// SkillsSchema from src/lib/schemas.ts:
   430‚ÜíSkillsSchema = z.object({
   431‚Üí  categories: z.array(z.object({
   432‚Üí    name: z.string(),
   433‚Üí    skills: z.array(z.string())  // <-- STRINGS ONLY!
   434‚Üí  }))
   435‚Üí});
   436‚Üí```
   437‚Üí
   438‚Üí**Before writing skills file**:
   439‚Üí1. Verify each skill is a plain string
   440‚Üí2. Move any evidence/level data to comments
   441‚Üí3. Test parse the YAML structure mentally
   442‚Üí
   443‚Üí### Phase 6: Validation & Gap Analysis
   444‚Üí
   445‚Üí```bash
   446‚Üí# Validate all content against Zod schemas
   447‚Üínpm run validate
   448‚Üí
   449‚Üí# Check for gaps
   450‚Üí```
   451‚Üí
   452‚Üí**Gap checklist**:
   453‚Üí- [ ] All required fields populated
   454‚Üí- [ ] No placeholder URLs (demo.com, example.com)
   455‚Üí- [ ] Metrics are specific, not vague ("improved" ‚Üí "improved by 40%")
   456‚Üí- [ ] Missing metrics marked with `[METRIC]` for user to fill (e.g., "Increased revenue by [METRIC]%")
   457‚Üí- [ ] Each experience has 3-4 highlights (focused, not exhaustive)
   458‚Üí- [ ] Product links included for every shipped product/tool
   459‚Üí- [ ] All dates in consistent format (YYYY or YYYY‚ÄìYY)
   460‚Üí

   543‚Üí
   544‚Üí---
   545‚Üí
   546‚Üí## Example Workflows
   547‚Üí
   548‚Üí### Workflow 1: Obsidian Vault Import
   549‚Üí
   550‚Üí```
   551‚ÜíUser: "I have an Obsidian vault at ~/Documents/Career-Notes with my work history"
   552‚Üí
   553‚ÜíSteps:
   554‚Üí1. Scan vault for relevant files (work, projects, reviews folders)
   555‚Üí2. Parse each markdown file, extract structured data
   556‚Üí3. Map to experience/index.yaml format
   557‚Üí4. Identify case study candidates
   558‚Üí5. Extract any testimonial quotes
   559‚Üí6. Validate and report gaps
   560‚Üí```
   561‚Üí
   562‚Üí### Workflow 2: LinkedIn Export + Resume
   563‚Üí
   564‚Üí```
   565‚ÜíUser: "I have a LinkedIn CSV export and my resume as text"
   566‚Üí
   567‚ÜíSteps:
   568‚Üí1. Parse CSV for positions, skills, recommendations
   569‚Üí2. Parse resume text for additional details
   570‚Üí3. Merge and deduplicate
   571‚Üí4. Enrich highlights with specific metrics
   572‚Üí5. Create skills taxonomy
   573‚Üí6. Validate against schemas
   574‚Üí```
   575‚Üí
   576‚Üí### Workflow 3: Zip Archive with Mixed Content
   577‚Üí
   578‚Üí```
   579‚ÜíUser: "I have a zip file with CSV files, text notes, and screenshots"
   580‚Üí
   581‚ÜíSteps:
   582‚Üí1. Extract archive to temp directory
   583‚Üí2. Inventory all files by type
   584‚Üí3. Process CSVs for structured data
   585‚Üí4. Process text files for testimonials/notes
   586‚Üí5. Catalog images for case study thumbnails
   587‚Üí6. Consolidate into content structure
   588‚Üí7. Clean up temp files
   589‚Üí```
   590‚Üí
   591‚Üí---
   592‚Üí
   593‚Üí## Quality Criteria
   594‚Üí
   595‚Üí### "Hired-on-Sight" Standard
   596‚Üí
   597‚ÜíEvery piece of content should pass this test:
   598‚Üí
   599‚Üí- **Specific**: Numbers, names, technologies ‚Äî not vague claims
   600‚Üí- **Verified**: Can point to source data
   601‚Üí- **Impactful**: Shows business/user value, not just activity
   602‚Üí- **Consistent**: Formatting, dates, terminology aligned
   603‚Üí- **Complete**: No "TODO" or placeholder content
   604‚Üí
   605‚Üí### Validation Commands
   606‚Üí
   607‚Üí```bash
   608‚Üí# Full content validation
   609‚Üínpm run validate
   610‚Üí
   611‚Üí# Build to catch any issues
   612‚Üínpm run build
   613‚Üí
   614‚Üí# Preview locally
   615‚Üínpm run dev
   616‚Üí```
   617‚Üí
   618‚Üí---
   619‚Üí
   620‚Üí## Tips
   621‚Üí
   622‚Üí- **Preserve source references**: Note which file each piece of data came from
   623‚Üí- **Prioritize metrics**: "Shipped feature" < "Shipped feature used by 10K users"
   624‚Üí- **Anonymize carefully**: If removing names, keep role context
   625‚Üí- **Check dates**: Ensure no overlapping periods, consistent formatting
   626‚Üí- **Cross-reference**: Same project might appear in experience AND as case study
   627‚Üí- **Images**: Store in `/public/images/`, reference as `/images/filename.png`
   628‚Üí
   629‚Üí---
   630‚Üí
   631‚Üí## Dependencies
   632‚Üí
   633‚Üí- Node.js (for validation scripts)
   634‚Üí- `npm run validate` command
   635‚Üí- Zod schemas in `src/lib/schemas.ts`
   636‚Üí
   637‚ÜíNo additional packages required.

    77‚Üí## Threat Categories
    78‚Üí
    79‚Üí### Category 1: Accuracy Failures
    80‚Üí
    81‚Üí#### Threat 1.1: Hallucination
    82‚Üí**Description:** AI generates achievements not present in knowledge base.
    83‚Üí
    84‚Üí| Attribute | Assessment |
    85‚Üí|-----------|------------|
    86‚Üí| Likelihood | Medium |
    87‚Üí| Impact | High |
    88‚Üí| Risk Level | **High** |
    89‚Üí
    90‚Üí**Attack Scenario:**
    91‚Üí```
    92‚ÜíUser: "Create variant for Coinbase"
    93‚ÜíAI: "Led cryptocurrency compliance initiatives resulting in $50M in
    94‚Üí     institutional assets under management"
    95‚Üí
    96‚ÜíProblem: $50M AUM was never stated in knowledge base
    97‚Üí```
    98‚Üí
    99‚Üí**Mitigation:**
   100‚Üí- Knowledge base as sole source of facts
   101‚Üí- Skill prompts explicitly forbid invention
   102‚Üí- Human review before publishing
   103‚Üí- Evaluation framework checks traceability
   104‚Üí
   105‚Üí**Detection:**
   106‚Üí- [ ] Manual claim-to-source audit
   107‚Üí- [ ] Future: Automated fact extraction and matching
   108‚Üí
   109‚Üí---
   110‚Üí
   111‚Üí#### Threat 1.2: Metric Inflation
   112‚Üí**Description:** AI rounds up or exaggerates numerical claims.
   113‚Üí
   114‚Üí| Attribute | Assessment |
   115‚Üí|-----------|------------|
   116‚Üí| Likelihood | Medium |
   117‚Üí| Impact | High |
   118‚Üí| Risk Level | **High** |
   119‚Üí
   120‚Üí**Attack Scenario:**
   121‚Üí```
   122‚ÜíKnowledge Base: "15√ó revenue growth"
   123‚ÜíGenerated: "Nearly 20√ó revenue growth"
   124‚Üí           "Order of magnitude improvement"
   125‚Üí
   126‚ÜíProblem: 15√ó became 20√ó or vague "order of magnitude"
   127‚Üí```
   128‚Üí
   129‚Üí**Mitigation:**
   130‚Üí- Metrics stored as exact values in knowledge base
   131‚Üí- Skill prompts require verbatim number usage
   132‚Üí- Evaluation framework checks metric accuracy
   133‚Üí
   134‚Üí**Detection:**
   135‚Üí- [ ] Regex extraction of numbers from output
   136‚Üí- [ ] Comparison to knowledge base metrics
   137‚Üí
   138‚Üí---
   139‚Üí
   140‚Üí#### Threat 1.3: Attribution Errors
   141‚Üí**Description:** Achievement attributed to wrong company or time period.
   142‚Üí
   143‚Üí| Attribute | Assessment |
   144‚Üí|-----------|------------|
   145‚Üí| Likelihood | Low |
   146‚Üí| Impact | High |
   147‚Üí| Risk Level | **Medium** |
   148‚Üí
   149‚Üí**Attack Scenario:**
   150‚Üí```
   151‚ÜíGenerated: "At Anchorage, I drove 15√ó revenue growth..."
   152‚Üí
   153‚ÜíProblem: 15√ó growth was at Ankr, not Anchorage
   154‚Üí```
   155‚Üí
   156‚Üí**Mitigation:**
   157‚Üí- Achievements explicitly tagged with company
   158‚Üí- Skill queries filter by company when generating
   159‚Üí- Human review catches misattribution
   160‚Üí
   161‚Üí---
   162‚Üí
   163‚Üí### Category 2: Relevance Failures
   164‚Üí
   165‚Üí#### Threat 2.1: Over-Optimization for Keywords
   166‚Üí**Description:** System stuffs keywords to game ATS without substance.
   167‚Üí
   168‚Üí| Attribute | Assessment |
   169‚Üí|-----------|------------|
   170‚Üí| Likelihood | Medium |
   171‚Üí| Impact | Medium |
   172‚Üí| Risk Level | **Medium** |
   173‚Üí
   174‚Üí**Attack Scenario:**
   175‚Üí```
   176‚ÜíJob Description mentions: "Kubernetes, Docker, CI/CD, microservices"
   177‚Üí
   178‚ÜíGenerated: "Extensive experience with Kubernetes orchestration, Docker
   179‚Üí           containerization, CI/CD pipelines, and microservices architecture
   180‚Üí           across multiple enterprise deployments..."
   181‚Üí
   182‚ÜíProblem: Keywords present but claims are generic/unsubstantiated
   183‚Üí```
   184‚Üí
   185‚Üí**Mitigation:**
   186‚Üí- Focus skill prompts on narrative relevance, not keyword matching
   187‚Üí- Require achievements to back up any skill claims
   188‚Üí- Evaluation rubric penalizes keyword stuffing
   189‚Üí
   190‚Üí---
   191‚Üí
   192‚Üí#### Threat 2.2: Irrelevant Personalization
   193‚Üí**Description:** Variant customization doesn't meaningfully fit the role.
   194‚Üí
   195‚Üí| Attribute | Assessment |
   196‚Üí|-----------|------------|
   197‚Üí| Likelihood | Medium |
   198‚Üí| Impact | Low |
   199‚Üí| Risk Level | **Low** |
   200‚Üí
   201‚Üí**Attack Scenario:**
   202‚Üí```
   203‚ÜíTarget: Platform PM at payments company
   204‚ÜíGenerated: Emphasizes crypto/Web3 experience without connecting to payments
   205‚Üí
   206‚ÜíProblem: Personalization is superficial, doesn't address role requirements
   207‚Üí```
   208‚Üí
   209‚Üí**Mitigation:**
   210‚Üí- Skill prompts require explicit mapping of JD requirements to achievements
   211‚Üí- Evaluation framework scores relevance
   212‚Üí- Iterate on low-scoring variants
   213‚Üí
   214‚Üí---
   215‚Üí
   216‚Üí### Category 3: Tone Failures
   217‚Üí
   218‚Üí#### Threat 3.1: Sycophancy
   219‚Üí**Description:** AI generates excessively flattering content about target company.
   220‚Üí
   221‚Üí| Attribute | Assessment |
   222‚Üí|-----------|------------|
   223‚Üí| Likelihood | Medium |
   224‚Üí| Impact | Medium |
   225‚Üí| Risk Level | **Medium** |
   226‚Üí
   227‚Üí**Attack Scenario:**
   228‚Üí```
   229‚ÜíGenerated: "I have long admired Stripe's revolutionary approach to payments
   230‚Üí           infrastructure. Your industry-leading platform represents exactly
   231‚Üí           the kind of transformative opportunity I've dreamed of..."
   232‚Üí
   233‚ÜíProblem: Sounds desperate and inauthentic
   234‚Üí```
   235‚Üí
   236‚Üí**Mitigation:**
   237‚Üí- Skill prompts explicitly prohibit company flattery
   238‚Üí- Evaluation rubric penalizes sycophancy
   239‚Üí- Tone check: "Would this embarrass me in an interview?"
   240‚Üí
   241‚Üí---
   242‚Üí
   243‚Üí#### Threat 3.2: Generic/Bland Output
   244‚Üí**Description:** Generated content lacks personality and distinctiveness.
   245‚Üí
   246‚Üí| Attribute | Assessment |
   247‚Üí|-----------|------------|
   248‚Üí| Likelihood | High |
   249‚Üí| Impact | Low |
   250‚Üí| Risk Level | **Medium** |
   251‚Üí
   252‚Üí**Attack Scenario:**
   253‚Üí```
   254‚ÜíGenerated: "Results-driven product manager with a track record of delivering
   255‚Üí           innovative solutions in fast-paced environments..."
   256‚Üí
   257‚ÜíProblem: Could describe anyone, no authentic voice
   258‚Üí```
   259‚Üí
   260‚Üí**Mitigation:**
   261‚Üí- Include voice/style guidance in skill prompts
   262‚Üí- Reference base portfolio tone
   263‚Üí- Evaluation rubric scores authenticity
   264‚Üí
   265‚Üí---
   266‚Üí
   267‚Üí### Category 4: Ethical Failures
   268‚Üí
   269‚Üí#### Threat 4.1: Deceptive Personalization
   270‚Üí**Description:** Variant implies deeper interest in company than exists.
   271‚Üí
   272‚Üí| Attribute | Assessment |
   273‚Üí|-----------|------------|
   274‚Üí| Likelihood | Medium |
   275‚Üí| Impact | Medium |
   276‚Üí| Risk Level | **Medium** |
   277‚Üí
   278‚Üí**Attack Scenario:**
   279‚Üí```
   280‚ÜíGenerated for 50 different companies, each implying specific interest:
   281‚Üí"I've been following [Company]'s work in [domain] and am particularly
   282‚Üí excited about [recent news]..."
   283‚Üí
   284‚ÜíProblem: Can't genuinely be excited about 50 companies
   285‚Üí```
   286‚Üí
   287‚Üí**Mitigation:**
   288‚Üí- Don't include "excitement" or "passion" claims
   289‚Üí- Focus on skill/experience fit, not emotional connection
   290‚Üí- Be honest if asked: "I use personalized variants"
   291‚Üí
   292‚Üí---
   293‚Üí
   294‚Üí#### Threat 4.2: Unfair Advantage
   295‚Üí**Description:** AI assistance creates uneven playing field.
   296‚Üí
   297‚Üí| Attribute | Assessment |
   298‚Üí|-----------|------------|
   299‚Üí| Likelihood | Low (philosophical) |
   300‚Üí| Impact | Low |
   301‚Üí| Risk Level | **Low** |
   302‚Üí
   303‚Üí**Analysis:**
   304‚ÜíThis tool helps present truth more effectively. It does not:
   305‚Üí- Fabricate credentials
   306‚Üí- Lie about experience
   307‚Üí- Bypass skill assessments
   308‚Üí
   309‚Üí**Position:**
   310‚ÜíUsing AI to organize and present real experience is no different than using a resume editor, career coach, or spell checker.
   311‚Üí
   312‚Üí---
   313‚Üí
   314‚Üí### Category 5: Privacy Failures
   315‚Üí
   316‚Üí#### Threat 5.1: Cross-Variant Contamination
   317‚Üí**Description:** Information from one variant leaks into another.
   318‚Üí
   319‚Üí| Attribute | Assessment |
   320‚Üí|-----------|------------|
   321‚Üí| Likelihood | Low |
   322‚Üí| Impact | Medium |
   323‚Üí| Risk Level | **Low** |
   324‚Üí
   325‚Üí**Attack Scenario:**
   326‚Üí```
   327‚ÜíStripe variant accidentally includes: "...following my conversations with
   328‚ÜíBloomberg about their trading platform..."
   329‚Üí
   330‚ÜíProblem: Reveals application activity to other companies
   331‚Üí```
   332‚Üí
   333‚Üí**Mitigation:**
   334‚Üí- Variants generated independently (no cross-references)
   335‚Üí- Skill prompts don't reference other applications
   336‚Üí- Human review catches leakage
   337‚Üí
   338‚Üí---
   339‚Üí
   340‚Üí#### Threat 5.2: Confidential Information Exposure
   341‚Üí**Description:** System reveals non-public information from previous employers.
   342‚Üí
   343‚Üí| Attribute | Assessment |
   344‚Üí|-----------|------------|
   345‚Üí| Likelihood | Medium |
   346‚Üí| Impact | High |
   347‚Üí| Risk Level | **High** |
   348‚Üí
   349‚Üí**Attack Scenario:**
   350‚Üí```
   351‚ÜíKnowledge base contains: "Managed $500M in institutional assets"
   352‚ÜíThis may be confidential information about Anchorage's AUM
   353‚Üí
   354‚ÜíProblem: Public disclosure of non-public business metrics
   355‚Üí```
   356‚Üí
   357‚Üí**Mitigation:**
   358‚Üí- Review all knowledge base entries for confidentiality
   359‚Üí- Use public information only (press releases, public filings)
   360‚Üí- When in doubt, use ranges or qualitative descriptions
   361‚Üí- Tag sensitive information in knowledge base
   362‚Üí

/**
 * ucv-cli ‚Äî Universal CV interactive workflow
 *
 * Goals:
 * - One entry point: npm run ucv-cli
 * - Persistent dashboard: see sync/eval/redteam/publish state at a glance
 * - Guided workflow: create ‚Üí sync ‚Üí eval ‚Üí redteam ‚Üí publish
 * - Safer by default: store full JDs in source-data/ (gitignored); ship only excerpts
 */

import { spawn } from 'child_process';

} from 'fs';

type PublishStatus = 'draft' | 'published';

  sequence?: string;
  name?: string;
  ctrl?: boolean;
  meta?: boolean;
  shift?: boolean;
};

type SyncStatus =
  | { kind: 'ok' }
  | { kind: 'error'; message: string };

type EvalStatus =
  | { kind: 'missing' }
  | { kind: 'unverified'; verified: number; claims: number }
  | { kind: 'ok'; verified: number; claims: number }
  | { kind: 'error'; message: string; verified?: number; claims?: number };

type RedteamStatus =
  | { kind: 'pass'; warns: number; fails: number }
  | { kind: 'warn'; warns: number; fails: number }
  | { kind: 'fail'; warns: number; fails: number }
  | { kind: 'error'; message: string };

type VariantMeta = {
  slug: string;
  company: string;
  role: string;
  companyKey?: string;
  roleKey?: string;
  sourceUrl?: string;
  generatedAt: string;
  jobDescription: string; // excerpt
  publishStatus: PublishStatus;
  publishedAt?: string;
};

type VariantRow = {
  meta: VariantMeta;
  sync: SyncStatus;
  eval: EvalStatus;
  redteam: RedteamStatus;
  next: string;
  // Raw machine-readable outputs (when available) for richer UI.
  evalResult?: Record<string, unknown>;
  redteamResult?: Record<string, unknown>;
};

type BottomPanelMode = 'activity' | 'eval' | 'redteam' | 'claims' | 'issues';

type Overlay =
  | { kind: 'actions'; selected: number }
  | { kind: 'claims'; focus: 'claims' | 'sources' | 'cta'; claimIndex: number; sourceIndex: number }
  | { kind: 'help' }
  | null;

type RunnerState = {
  running: boolean;
  title: string;
  phase?: 'Sync' | 'Evaluate' | 'Verify' | 'Red Team' | 'Pipeline' | 'Publish';
  slug?: string;
  startedAt: number;
  lines: string[];
  code?: number;
  logFile?: string;
  // A single-line, demo-friendly description of what's happening right now.

Every skill starts with YAML frontmatter:

```yaml

name: [skill-name]

## When Claude Should Use This

- [Trigger condition 1]
- [Trigger condition 2]
- [Trigger condition 3]

## [Main Content Sections]
[Detailed instructions, workflows, patterns]
```

**Frontmatter fields:**
- `name` - matches directory name (kebab-case)
- `description` - short tagline (appears in skill picker)

## Evaluation and Red-Teaming Systems - Complete Analysis

I've thoroughly explored the evaluation and red-teaming infrastructure for variants. Here's what I found:

---

## 1. **EVALUATION SYSTEM: Claims Extraction & Verification**

### Core Purpose
`/Users/dfotesco/Portfolio/portfolio/scripts/evaluate-variants.ts` (678 lines) is a strict verification framework that:
- Extracts metric-based "claims" from variant overrides
- Links each claim to knowledge base sources
- Creates a machine-checkable claims ledger
- Enables regression detection via content hashing

### Claims Extraction Pipeline

**What triggers a claim?** (Lines 243-250)
- Must contain metric signal: digits, `%`, `$`, `√ó` symbols, or quantifier words (`zero`, `billions`, `millions`, etc.)
- Sentences split on periods, question marks, exclamation marks, newlines
- Each claim gets a SHA1-based ID: `metric-<10char-hash>`

**Anchor Extraction** (Lines 212-241)
Searches for specific metric patterns:
- Dollar amounts: `$[0-9][0-9.,]*[KMB]?+?`
- Percentages: `[0-9]%`
- Multipliers: `[0-9]x` or `√ó`
- Increments: `[0-9]+`
- Time periods: `[0-9] weeks?|months?|years?|days?`
- Scale notations: `[0-9]K|M|B`
- Parenthetical metadata: `(City, State)` style
- Quantifier words: "billions", "millions", "zero", etc.

**Example Claim** (from meta-business-ai-pm.claims.yaml):
```yaml
- id: metric-72282af8fb
  location: overrides.about.bio[0]
  text: "At Dapper Labs I shipped an AI support agent handling 1,000+ questions weekly with 98% accuracy"
  anchors:
    - 98%
    - 000+
  verified:
    status: verified
    sources:
      - content/experience/index.yaml
    notes: "Experience index: 'kapa.ai support bot answering 1,000+ questions in 4 weeks with 98% accuracy'"
```

### Source Matching Algorithm (Lines 291-320)

**Two-part scoring:**
1. **Anchor Score** = matched anchors / total anchors (hard evidence)
2. **Overlap Score** = matched tokens / claim tokens (soft relevance)
   - Token filtering: removes words <4 chars, common stopwords
   - Combined score: `min(1, anchorScore + 0.15 * overlapScore)`

**Top 5 candidate sources** ranked by score. Example:
```yaml
candidateSources:
  - path: content/knowledge/achievements/xbox-royalties-ethereum.yaml
    score: 1.0
    matchedAnchors: [millions]
    note: "anchors 1/1 ‚Ä¢ overlap 28%"
```

### Claims Ledger Format (YAML)

**Structure:**
```yaml
version: 1
variant:
  slug: <slug>
  variantFile: content/variants/<slug>.yaml
  contentHash: <sha256-of-variant-content>
  evaluatedAt: <ISO8601>
claims:
  - id: metric-<hash>
    location: <path.to.claim>
    text: <full sentence>
    anchors: [list of extracted metrics]
    candidateSources: [scored candidates]
    verified:
      status: verified | unverified
      sources: [verified source paths with anchors]
      notes: [human notes]
```

### Verification Workflow (Lines 412-440)

**checkLedgerStrict() performs 4 checks:**

1. **Content Hash Validation**: If `contentHash` changed ‚Üí re-run eval
2. **Claim Verification Status**: All claims must be `verified`
3. **Source File Existence**: Source path must exist on disk
4. **Anchor Presence**: Each verified anchor must still appear in source file (regression detection)

**Example failure mode:**
```
Error: Anchor missing for metric-abc123: '98%' not found in content/experience/index.yaml
```
This catches when someone deletes or changes source content after claims are verified.

### CLI Commands

```bash
npm run eval:variant -- --slug <slug>          # Evaluate one variant
npm run eval:all                                # Evaluate all variants
npm run eval:check                              # Gate: strict ledger verification
npm run eval:variant -- --verify id=path       # Manually verify a claim
```

### Core Purpose
`/Users/dfotesco/Portfolio/portfolio/scripts/redteam.ts` (493 lines) runs **8 parallel safety scans**:

- Confidentiality/NDA language (FAIL)
- Sycophancy/flattery (WARN)
- Metric inflation indicators (WARN)
- Prompt injection in job descriptions (WARN)
- Job description exposure risk (WARN)

## 3. **THREAT MODEL & RISK FRAMEWORK**

### Threat Categories (from `/Users/dfotesco/Portfolio/portfolio/capstone/develop/red-teaming.md`)

#### Category 1: Accuracy (HIGH RISK)
- **Hallucination** (Medium likelihood, High impact)
  - AI invents achievements not in knowledge base
  - Mitigation: KB as sole source, human review, eval framework

- **Metric Inflation** (Medium likelihood, High impact)
  - Numbers rounded up ("nearly 20√ó" instead of "15√ó")
  - Mitigation: Exact values in KB, verbatim usage requirement

- **Attribution Errors** (Low likelihood, High impact)
  - Achievement credited to wrong company/time
  - Mitigation: Company tagging in achievements

#### Category 2: Relevance (MEDIUM RISK)
- **Keyword Stuffing** (Medium likelihood, Medium impact)
  - Generic keywords without substantiation
  - Mitigation: Narrative focus in prompts, evaluation rubric

#### Category 3: Tone (MEDIUM RISK)
- **Sycophancy** (Medium likelihood, Medium impact)
  - "Thrilled to join your revolutionary company"
  - Mitigation: Explicit anti-flattery checks in evaluation

#### Category 4: Ethics (MEDIUM RISK)
- **Deceptive Personalization** (Medium likelihood, Medium impact)
  - Implying false passion for 50 target companies
  - Mitigation: Don't include emotional claims, be transparent

#### Category 5: Privacy (HIGH RISK - Needs Audit)
- **Confidential Information Exposure** (Medium likelihood, High impact)
  - Publishing non-public company metrics
  - Mitigation: Audit KB for public-only info, use ranges

---

## 4. **QUALITY GATES & VERIFICATION WORKFLOW**

### Pre-Publication Checklist (from red-teaming.md)
```
‚ñ° All metrics verified against knowledge base
‚ñ° No hallucinated achievements
‚ñ° No sycophantic language
‚ñ° No confidential information
‚ñ° Attribution correct (right company, right period)
‚ñ° Tone consistent with base portfolio
‚ñ° Would I defend every claim in an interview?
```

### Gate Thresholds

| Gate | Command | Pass Criteria | Strictness |
|------|---------|---------------|-----------|
| **Evaluation** | `npm run eval:check` | All claims verified + anchors present | Medium |
| **Red Team** | `npm run redteam:check` | Zero FAIL findings, WARN allowed | Permissive |
| **Red Team Strict** | `npm run redteam:check --strict` | Zero FAIL + zero WARN | Strict |

### Real-World Example: Unverified State

From bloomberg-technical-product-manager.claims.yaml (earlier, unsynced):
```yaml
- id: metric-1080fe1903
  location: overrides.hero.subheadline
  text: "Senior Technical PM with 8 years shipping..."
  anchors: [8 years]
  candidateSources:
    - path: content/experience/index.yaml
      score: 0.09
  verified:
    status: unverified          # ‚Üê Not yet verified!
    sources: []
```
This would FAIL gate until manually verified via:
```bash
npm run eval:variant -- --slug bloomberg-technical-product-manager \
  --verify metric-1080fe1903=content/experience/index.yaml
```

---

## 5. **INTEGRATION WITH VARIANT LIFECYCLE**

### Workflow Diagram
```
content/variants/<slug>.yaml (canonical source)
            ‚Üì
[eval:variant] ‚Üí extracts claims ‚Üí capstone/develop/evals/<slug>.claims.yaml
            ‚Üì
[eval:check] ‚Üí validates anchors ‚Üí PASS/FAIL gate
            ‚Üì
[redteam:variant] ‚Üí safety scans ‚Üí capstone/develop/redteam/<slug>.redteam.md
            ‚Üì
[redteam:check] ‚Üí gates publication ‚Üí PASS/FAIL gate
            ‚Üì
content/variants/<slug>.json (runtime artifact)
```

### Hash-Based Regression Detection
- **contentHash** computed from: slug, company, role, overrides, relevance
- If variant.yaml changes ‚Üí hash changes ‚Üí old ledger invalidates
- Forces re-evaluation before gate passes
- **This prevents stale verification claims**

---

## 6. **KEY INSIGHTS**

**Design Philosophy:**
1. **Traceability over Automation**: Every claim anchored to a source file
2. **Strict by Default**: Gate requires 100% verified claims, not just "pass human review"
3. **Regression Prevention**: Hash-based invalidation catches content changes
4. **Composable Checks**: 8 independent scans can fail in isolation or together
5. **Human-in-Loop**: `--verify` flag allows manual claim approval after AI generation

**Safety Priorities:**
1. Secrets/Confidential/Attribution (HARD FAIL)
2. Metric Inflation (HARD FAIL via eval gate)
3. Sycophancy/Tone (WARN, reviewer decides)
4. Exposure Risk (WARN, reviewer decides)

**Verification is Strongest Guarantee:**
- Not just "does this claim feel true"
- Not just "did an AI reviewer approve it"
- **Actual source file must contain the exact anchor text**
- Regression detection ensures source doesn't disappear after verification

### 1. What UCV-CLI Does

**UCV-CLI** (Universal CV - Command Line Interface) is an **interactive TUI (Terminal User Interface)** for managing job-targeted CV variants through a complete quality pipeline:

- **Variant Creation**: Create new job-specific CV variants from templates (Blank, Technical PM, Senior PM, Crypto PM)
- **Sync**: Convert YAML variant definitions ‚Üí JSON runtime artifacts
- **Evaluate**: Extract metric claims from variant content and find/score candidate sources to back them up
- **Verify**: Human-in-the-loop: review and lock verified sources into claims ledger
- **Red Team**: Security/quality scanning for prompt injection, secrets, inconsistencies, and quality issues
- **Publish**: Mark variants as published (with git integration)

The CLI provides a persistent dashboard showing all variants and their status across all phases.

# Plan: Create `generate-variant` Claude Code Skill

## Overview

Create a comprehensive skill that guides Claude through variant generation with built-in quality gates, leveraging the ucv-cli infrastructure and learnings from the Galaxy variant exercise.

---

## Key Learnings from Galaxy Variant Exercise

### Process Learnings
1. **Path-based routing** ‚Äî Variants use `/company/role` not `?variant=slug`
2. **Claims verification is critical** ‚Äî All metric claims must trace to knowledge base sources
3. **Existing connections are gold** ‚Äî Lead with what you've already proven (Galaxy was already an Anchorage client)
4. **Eval ‚Üí Verify ‚Üí Redteam flow** ‚Äî Each phase catches different issues

### Design Learnings
5. **Signature headline stays** ‚Äî "Building at the edge of trust" is the brand; `companyAccent` augments it
6. **Inline > separate line** ‚Äî `trust ‚Äî with Galaxy` reads as one thought, doesn't add visual weight
7. **Micro-tweaks compound** ‚Äî Small opacity/size adjustments (0.35em ‚Üí 0.28em) create polish

---
name: generate-variant
description: Generate job-targeted CV variants with built-in quality gates. Queries knowledge base, customizes content, runs eval/redteam pipeline.

# Generate Variant

## When Claude Should Use This
- User provides a job description or job URL
- User asks to create a variant for a specific company/role
- User says "generate variant", "create variant", "tailor CV for [company]"

## Phase 1: Job Analysis
1. Extract company name, role title, key requirements
2. Identify must-have vs nice-to-have qualifications
3. Note specific technologies, domains, or experiences mentioned
4. Determine variant slug: `{company}-{role}` (kebab-case)

## Phase 2: Knowledge Base Query
1. Search achievements for matching skills/domains
2. Identify stories that demonstrate required competencies
3. Find existing client relationships (like Galaxy‚ÜíAnchorage)
4. Rank by relevance score (0.0-1.0)

## Phase 3: Content Generation
1. **Hero Section**
   - status: Keep simple ("Open to Product Roles")
   - headline: Preserve signature, add companyAccent inline
   - subheadline: Tailored elevator pitch with company connection

2. **About Section**
   - tagline: One-line positioning
   - bio: Two paragraphs (recent experience ‚Üí career arc + vision)
   - stats: Three punchy metrics from knowledge base

3. **Relevance Scoring**
   - caseStudies: Rank by JD fit with reasoning
   - skills: Category relevance scores
   - sections: Toggle visibility based on role

## Phase 4: Variant File Creation
1. Create `content/variants/{slug}.yaml`
2. Run `npm run variants:sync -- --slug {slug}`
3. Verify JSON generated at `content/variants/{slug}.json`

## Phase 5: Evaluation Pipeline
1. Run `npm run eval:variant -- --slug {slug}`
2. Review extracted claims (metrics with anchors)
3. Verify each claim against knowledge base source
4. Use `--verify id=path` for each claim
5. Target: 100% claims verified

## Phase 6: Red Team Pipeline
1. Run `npm run redteam:variant -- --slug {slug}`
2. Review FAIL/WARN findings
3. Fix any issues:
   - RT-ACC-CLAIMS: Verify all claims
   - RT-SEC-SECRETS: Remove any tokens
   - RT-TONE-SYCOPHANCY: Remove flattery
   - RT-PRIV-JD: Consider truncating long JD

## Phase 7: Final Review
1. Open variant in browser: `http://localhost:5173/{company}/{role}`
2. Check visual hierarchy and typography
3. Verify companyAccent renders correctly
4. Confirm stats are accurate and punchy

## Quality Checklist
- [ ] All claims verified against knowledge base
- [ ] No hallucinated achievements
- [ ] Company connection established (existing client? industry overlap?)
- [ ] Signature headline preserved with companyAccent
- [ ] Stats are verifiable and impactful
- [ ] Red team passes (0 FAIL, minimal WARN)
- [ ] Would defend every claim in an interview

## File Locations Reference
- Variant YAML: `content/variants/{slug}.yaml`
- Variant JSON: `content/variants/{slug}.json`
- Claims Ledger: `capstone/develop/evals/{slug}.claims.yaml`
- Eval Report: `capstone/develop/evals/{slug}.eval.md`
- Redteam Report: `capstone/develop/redteam/{slug}.redteam.md`
- Knowledge Base: `content/knowledge/achievements/*.yaml`
- Template: `content/variants/_template.yaml`

## Commands Reference
\```bash
npm run variants:sync -- --slug {slug}     # YAML ‚Üí JSON
npm run eval:variant -- --slug {slug}      # Extract claims
npm run eval:variant -- --slug {slug} --verify {id}={path}  # Verify claim
npm run redteam:variant -- --slug {slug}   # Safety scan
npm run dev                                 # Preview at localhost:5173
\```
\```

```md
---
name: generate-variant
description: Generate job-targeted CV variants with built-in quality gates. Queries knowledge base, customizes content, runs eval/redteam pipeline.
---

# Generate Variant

Generate personalized portfolio variants for specific job opportunities, with full traceability and quality verification.

## When Claude Should Use This

Activate when the user:
- Provides a job description or job URL
- Asks to create a variant for a specific company/role
- Says "generate variant", "create variant", "tailor CV for [company]"
- Wants to apply for a specific position

## Critical Design Principles

**From Galaxy Variant Exercise:**
1. **Signature headline stays** ‚Äî "Building at the edge of trust" is the brand
2. **companyAccent is REQUIRED** ‚Äî Add inline company name (`‚Äî with {Company}`)
3. **Existing connections are gold** ‚Äî Lead with what you've already proven
4. **Stats must be verifiable** ‚Äî Every metric traced to knowledge base
5. **Pause between phases** ‚Äî Get user approval before proceeding

---

## Phase 1: Job Analysis

**Goal:** Extract key requirements from the job description.

1. Identify:
   - Company name
   - Role title
   - Must-have qualifications
   - Nice-to-have qualifications
   - Specific technologies/domains mentioned
   - Team structure and reporting

2. Generate slug: `{company}-{role}` (kebab-case, e.g., `galaxy-pm`)

3. Check for existing variants:
   \```bash
   ls content/variants/ | grep -i {company}
   \```

**Output:** Summary of requirements to user for confirmation.

---

## Phase 2: Knowledge Base Query

**Goal:** Find matching achievements and stories.

1. Search achievements:
   \```bash
   ls content/knowledge/achievements/
   \```

2. Read relevant achievement files matching JD requirements

3. Look for existing client relationships:
   - Search for company name in achievements/stories
   - Example: Galaxy was already an Anchorage client (ETH staking)

4. Rank matches by relevance (0.0-1.0):
   - Direct skill match: 0.9-1.0
   - Related experience: 0.7-0.9
   - Transferable skills: 0.5-0.7

**Output:** List of relevant achievements with relevance scores.

---

## Phase 3: Content Generation

**IMPORTANT:** Invoke `dmitrii-writing-style` skill before writing bio content.

### Hero Section

\```yaml
hero:
  status: "Open to Product Roles"  # Keep simple
  headline:
    - text: "Building"
      style: "italic"
    - text: "at the edge of"
      style: "muted"
    - text: "trust"
      style: "accent"
  companyAccent:  # REQUIRED
    - text: "with"
      style: "muted"
    - text: "{Company}"
      style: "accent"
  subheadline: >
    [Tailored elevator pitch mentioning company connection]
\```

### About Section

\```yaml
about:
  tagline: >
    [One-line positioning statement]
  bio:
    - >

    - >

\```yaml
relevance:
  caseStudies:
    - slug: "[most-relevant]"
      relevanceScore: 1.0
      reasoning: "[Why this matches JD]"
    # ... ranked list
  skills:
    - category: "[Top category]"
      relevanceScore: 1.0
    # ... ranked list
\```

**PAUSE:** Show generated content to user for review before proceeding.

## Phase 4: Variant File Creation

1. Create variant YAML:
   \```bash
   # Write to content/variants/{slug}.yaml
   \```

2. Sync to JSON:
   \```bash
   npm run variants:sync -- --slug {slug}
   \```

3. Verify JSON created:
   \```bash
   ls content/variants/{slug}.json
   \```

---

## Phase 5: Evaluation Pipeline

1. Run evaluation:
   \```bash
   npm run eval:variant -- --slug {slug}
   \```

2. Review extracted claims (metrics with anchors)

3. For each unverified claim, verify against knowledge base:
   \```bash
   npm run eval:variant -- --slug {slug} --verify {claim-id}={source-path}
   \```

4. Target: **100% claims verified**

**PAUSE:** Show claims status to user before proceeding.

---

## Phase 6: Red Team Pipeline

1. Run red team scan:
   \```bash
   npm run redteam:variant -- --slug {slug}
   \```

2. Review findings:
   - **FAIL** ‚Äî Must fix before publishing
   - **WARN** ‚Äî Review and decide

3. Common issues and fixes:
   | Check | Issue | Fix |
   |-------|-------|-----|
   | RT-ACC-CLAIMS | Unverified claims | Run Phase 5 verification |
   | RT-SEC-SECRETS | Tokens in content | Remove sensitive data |
   | RT-TONE-SYCOPHANCY | Flattery detected | Rewrite objectively |
   | RT-PRIV-JD | Long JD exposed | Truncate in YAML |

**PAUSE:** Show redteam results to user for approval.

---

## Phase 7: Final Review

1. Start dev server if not running:
   \```bash
   npm run dev
   \```

2. Open variant in browser:
   \```
   http://localhost:5173/{company}/{role}
   \```

3. Visual checklist:
   - [ ] companyAccent renders inline after "trust"
   - [ ] Stats are visible and accurate
   - [ ] Bio reads naturally
   - [ ] Case studies are relevant

4. Offer to commit if approved.

---

## Quality Checklist

Before marking variant complete:

- [ ] All claims verified against knowledge base
- [ ] No hallucinated achievements
- [ ] Company connection established (existing client? industry overlap?)
- [ ] Signature headline preserved with companyAccent (REQUIRED)
- [ ] Stats are verifiable and impactful
- [ ] Red team passes (0 FAIL, minimal WARN)
- [ ] Would defend every claim in an interview
- [ ] Writing style matches dmitrii-writing-style
