     1‚Üí---
     2‚Üíname: run-tests
     3‚Üídescription: Run the test suite and identify new tests needed for recent code changes. Use when verifying changes work correctly or when asked to run tests.
     4‚Üí---
     5‚Üí
     6‚Üí# Run Tests
     7‚Üí
     8‚Üí## Overview
     9‚Üí
    10‚ÜíThis skill runs the existing test suite and analyzes recent code changes to identify what new tests should be written to maintain coverage.
    11‚Üí
    12‚Üí## When to Use This Skill
    13‚Üí
    14‚ÜíActivate when the user:
    15‚Üí- Says "run tests" or "/run-tests"
    16‚Üí- Asks to verify recent changes
    17‚Üí- Wants to know what tests are needed for new code
    18‚Üí- Asks about test coverage for recent updates
    19‚Üí
    20‚Üí## Execution Steps
    21‚Üí
    22‚Üí### Step 1: Run Existing Tests
    23‚Üí
    24‚Üí```bash
    25‚Üínpm run test
    26‚Üí```
    27‚Üí
    28‚ÜíReport results:
    29‚Üí- Number of tests passed/failed
    30‚Üí- Any failing test details
    31‚Üí- Test duration
    32‚Üí
    33‚Üí### Step 2: Identify Recent Changes
    34‚Üí
    35‚ÜíCheck git status and recent commits:
    36‚Üí
    37‚Üí```bash
    38‚Üígit diff --name-only HEAD~5
    39‚Üígit diff --cached --name-only
    40‚Üígit status --porcelain
    41‚Üí```
    42‚Üí
    43‚ÜíFocus on:
    44‚Üí- Modified `.tsx` and `.ts` files in `src/`
    45‚Üí- New components or features
    46‚Üí- Changes to existing components
    47‚Üí
    48‚Üí### Step 3: Analyze Test Coverage Gaps
    49‚Üí
    50‚ÜíFor each changed file, determine if tests exist:
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí| Source File | Test File Location |
    53‚Üí|-------------|-------------------|
    54‚Üí| `src/components/sections/*.tsx` | `src/tests/design-system/components.test.tsx` |
    55‚Üí| `src/components/case-study/*.tsx` | `src/tests/case-study/case-study.test.tsx` |
    56‚Üí| `src/components/Blog.tsx` | `src/tests/blog/blog-ux-features.test.tsx` |
    57‚Üí| `src/lib/*.ts` | `src/tests/validation/content-validation.test.ts` |
    58‚Üí| Navigation changes | `src/tests/navigation/navigation.test.tsx` |
    59‚Üí| Mobile-specific | `src/tests/mobile/mobile.test.tsx` |
    60‚Üí| Theme/CSS changes | `src/tests/design-system/css-variables.test.ts` |
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí### Step 4: Recommend New Tests
    63‚Üí
    64‚ÜíFor each uncovered change, suggest specific tests following the project patterns:
    65‚Üí
    66‚Üí**Test Pattern Template:**
    67‚Üí```tsx
    68‚Üíimport { render, screen } from '@testing-library/react';
    69‚Üíimport { ThemeProvider } from '../../context/ThemeContext';
    70‚Üíimport { VariantProvider } from '../../context/VariantContext';
    71‚Üíimport { profile } from '../../lib/content';
    72‚Üí
    73‚Üíconst TestWrapper = ({ children }: { children: React.ReactNode }) => (
    74‚Üí    <VariantProvider profile={profile}>
    75‚Üí        <ThemeProvider>{children}</ThemeProvider>
    76‚Üí    </VariantProvider>
    77‚Üí);
    78‚Üí
    79‚Üídescribe('[ComponentName]', () => {
    80‚Üí    it('should [expected behavior]', () => {
    81‚Üí        render(
    82‚Üí            <TestWrapper>
    83‚Üí                <ComponentName {...props} />
    84‚Üí            </TestWrapper>
    85‚Üí        );
    86‚Üí
    87‚Üí        expect(/* assertion */).toBe(/* expected */);
    88‚Üí    });
    89‚Üí});
    90‚Üí```
    91‚Üí
    92‚Üí## Output Format
    93‚Üí
    94‚Üí```
    95‚Üí## Test Results
    96‚Üí
    97‚Üí**Status**: ‚úÖ All passing | ‚ùå X failures
    98‚Üí**Tests**: X passed, X failed, X total
    99‚Üí**Duration**: Xs
   100‚Üí
   101‚Üí### Failures (if any)
   102‚Üí- `test name`: error message
   103‚Üí
   104‚Üí---
   105‚Üí
   106‚Üí## Recent Changes Analyzed
   107‚Üí
   108‚Üí| File | Change Type | Has Tests |
   109‚Üí|------|-------------|-----------|
   110‚Üí| src/components/sections/ExperienceSection.tsx | Modified | ‚úÖ Partial |
   111‚Üí
   112‚Üí---
   113‚Üí
   114‚Üí## Recommended New Tests
   115‚Üí
   116‚Üí### 1. [Test Name]
   117‚Üí**File**: `src/tests/[path]/[file].test.tsx`
   118‚Üí**Covers**: [what it tests]
   119‚Üí
   120‚Üí```tsx
   121‚Üí[test code suggestion]
   122‚Üí```
   123‚Üí
   124‚Üí### 2. ...
   125‚Üí```
   126‚Üí
   127‚Üí## Test Categories
   128‚Üí
   129‚Üí### Component Tests
   130‚Üí- Render without crashing
   131‚Üí- Uses CSS variables (not hardcoded colors)
   132‚Üí- Correct props handling
   133‚Üí- User interactions (clicks, hovers)
   134‚Üí- Accessibility attributes
   135‚Üí
   136‚Üí### Integration Tests
   137‚Üí- Data flows correctly from content files
   138‚Üí- Links render with correct URLs
   139‚Üí- Conditional rendering works
   140‚Üí
   141‚Üí### Responsive Tests
   142‚Üí- Mobile layout differences
   143‚Üí- Tablet breakpoints
   144‚Üí- Desktop behavior
   145‚Üí
   146‚Üí## Common Test Assertions
   147‚Üí
   148‚Üí```tsx
   149‚Üí// Element exists
   150‚Üíexpect(screen.getByText('text')).toBeInTheDocument();
   151‚Üí
   152‚Üí// Has attribute
   153‚Üíexpect(element).toHaveAttribute('href', 'url');
   154‚Üí
   155‚Üí// CSS variable usage
   156‚Üíexpect(element?.style.color).toContain('var(--color-');
   157‚Üí
   158‚Üí// Link behavior
   159‚Üíexpect(link).toHaveAttribute('target', '_blank');
   160‚Üíexpect(link).toHaveAttribute('rel', 'noopener noreferrer');
   161‚Üí```
   162‚Üí
   163‚Üí## File Locations
   164‚Üí
   165‚Üí| Purpose | Path |
   166‚Üí|---------|------|
   167‚Üí| Run tests | `npm run test` |
   168‚Üí| Watch mode | `npm run test:watch` |
   169‚Üí| Design system only | `npm run test:design-system` |
   170‚Üí| Test config | `vitest.config.ts` (if exists) or `vite.config.ts` |
   171‚Üí| Test setup | `src/tests/setup.ts` (if exists) |

   153‚Üí## üéØ Hired-on-Sight Polish (Target: 9/10)

   195‚Üí## Color System

   199‚ÜíAll colors are defined as CSS custom properties in `/styles/globals.css`:

   208‚Üí#### Light Mode

   225‚Üí### Using Colors

   234‚Üí
   235‚Üí## Typography
   236‚Üí
   237‚Üí### Font Families

   239‚Üí- **Instrument Serif** (Italic): Headlines, accent text

    16‚Üí## Technical Constraints
    17‚Üí
    18‚Üí| Metric | Limit | Rationale |
    19‚Üí|--------|-------|-----------|
    20‚Üí| **Initial Bundle** | < 200KB (Gzipped) | SEO & Mobile LCP performance |
    21‚Üí| **Animation Rate** | 60 FPS | Premium "smooth" feel requirement |
    22‚Üí| **Type Safety** | 100% Zod | Data integrity for YAML-to-JSON pipeline |

   117‚Üí### Key Patterns
   118‚Üí
   119‚Üí1. **Inline Styles with CSS Variables**: Components use inline `style` props with CSS variables
   120‚Üí   ```tsx
   121‚Üí   style={{ color: 'var(--color-text-primary)' }}
   122‚Üí   ```
   123‚Üí
   124‚Üí2. **Theme via data-attribute**: Theme switching uses `data-theme` on `<html>`
   125‚Üí   ```css
   126‚Üí   [data-theme="light"] { --color-background: #fafafa; }
   127‚Üí   ```
   128‚Üí
   129‚Üí3. **ThemeContext**: Provides `isDark`, `toggleTheme`, `theme` - but NOT colors (deprecated)
   130‚Üí
   131‚Üí4. **Universal CV - Variant System**: Portfolio personalization for job applications
   132‚Üí   - Base profile + variant overrides = personalized experience
   133‚Üí   - Dynamic routes via HashRouter (`/#/:company/:role`)
   134‚Üí   - VariantContext provides merged profile to components
   135‚Üí   - Sections receive `profile` prop from context (not direct imports)

   138‚Üí
   139‚Üí## Universal CV System
   140‚Üí
   141‚Üí### Overview
   142‚Üí
   143‚ÜíThe Universal CV system creates personalized portfolio variants tailored to specific job applications using AI-generated overrides of the base profile.
   144‚Üí
   145‚Üí**Live Examples:**
   146‚Üí- Base: `https://edgeoftrust.com/#/`
   147‚Üí- Bloomberg TPM: `https://edgeoftrust.com/#/bloomberg/technical-product-manager`
   148‚Üí- Gensyn TPM: `https://edgeoftrust.com/#/gensyn/technical-product-manager`
   149‚Üí
   150‚Üí### Architecture
   151‚Üí
   152‚Üí**Data Flow:**
   153‚Üí```
   154‚ÜíURL (/#/company/role)
   155‚Üí  ‚Üí React Router captures params
   156‚Üí  ‚Üí VariantPortfolio.tsx loads variant JSON
   157‚Üí  ‚Üí variants.ts: mergeProfile(base + overrides)
   158‚Üí  ‚Üí VariantContext provides merged profile
   159‚Üí  ‚Üí Portfolio.tsx receives from context
   160‚Üí  ‚Üí Sections (Hero, About, etc.) receive profile prop
   161‚Üí  ‚Üí Personalized content rendered
   162‚Üí```
   163‚Üí
   164‚Üí**Key Files:**
   165‚Üí- `src/context/VariantContext.tsx` - Profile injection system
   166‚Üí- `src/pages/VariantPortfolio.tsx` - Dynamic variant loader
   167‚Üí- `src/lib/variants.ts` - Loading + merging logic
   168‚Üí- `src/types/variant.ts` - Type definitions
   169‚Üí- `scripts/generate-cv.ts` - CLI generator (243 lines)
   170‚Üí- `content/variants/*.{yaml,json}` - Variant data
   171‚Üí
   172‚Üí### Variant Schema
   173‚Üí
   174‚Üí```typescript
   175‚Üíinterface Variant {
   176‚Üí  metadata: {
   177‚Üí    company: string;
   178‚Üí    role: string;
   179‚Üí    slug: string;
   180‚Üí    generatedAt: string;
   181‚Üí    jobDescription: string;
   182‚Üí    generationModel?: string;
   183‚Üí  };
   184‚Üí  overrides: {
   185‚Üí    hero?: {
   186‚Üí      status?: string;
   187‚Üí      headline?: HeadlineSegment[];
   188‚Üí      subheadline?: string;
   189‚Üí    };
   190‚Üí    about?: {
   191‚Üí      tagline?: string;
   192‚Üí      bio?: string[];
   193‚Üí      stats?: Stat[];
   194‚Üí    };
   195‚Üí    sections?: {
   196‚Üí      beyondWork?: boolean;
   197‚Üí      blog?: boolean;
   198‚Üí      onchainIdentity?: boolean;
   199‚Üí      skills?: boolean;
   200‚Üí      passionProjects?: boolean;
   201‚Üí    };
   202‚Üí  };
   203‚Üí  relevance?: {
   204‚Üí    caseStudies?: Array<{ slug: string; relevanceScore: number; reasoning?: string }>;
   205‚Üí    skills?: Array<{ category: string; relevanceScore: number }>;
   206‚Üí    projects?: Array<{ slug: string; relevanceScore: number; reasoning?: string }>;
   207‚Üí  };
   208‚Üí}
   209‚Üí```
   210‚Üí
   211‚Üí### Creating Variants
   212‚Üí
   213‚Üí**CLI Generator:**
   214‚Üí```bash
   215‚Üínpm run generate:cv -- \
   216‚Üí  --company "Company" \
   217‚Üí  --role "Role Title" \
   218‚Üí  --jd "./job-description.txt" \
   219‚Üí  --provider gemini
   220‚Üí```
   221‚Üí
   222‚Üí**Supported Providers:**
   223‚Üí- Claude (Anthropic): `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`
   224‚Üí- OpenAI: `OPENAI_API_KEY`
   225‚Üí- Gemini (Google): `GEMINI_API_KEY`
   226‚Üí
   227‚Üí### Component Integration
   228‚Üí
   229‚Üí**IMPORTANT**: Sections that show personalized content MUST receive `profile` as a prop:
   230‚Üí
   231‚Üí```tsx
   232‚Üí// ‚úÖ CORRECT - Receives profile from context
   233‚Üífunction HeroSection({ profile, isMobile }: { profile: Profile; isMobile: boolean }) {
   234‚Üí  const { hero } = profile;  // Uses variant profile
   235‚Üí  // ...
   236‚Üí}
   237‚Üí
   238‚Üí// ‚ùå INCORRECT - Direct import bypasses variants
   239‚Üíimport { profile } from '../lib/content';
   240‚Üífunction HeroSection({ isMobile }: { isMobile: boolean }) {
   241‚Üí  const { hero } = profile;  // Always uses base profile!
   242‚Üí  // ...
   243‚Üí}
   244‚Üí```
   245‚Üí
   246‚Üí**Updated Components:**
   247‚Üí- `HeroSection.tsx` - Receives `profile` prop
   248‚Üí- `AboutSection.tsx` - Receives `profile` prop
   249‚Üí- `CertificationsSection.tsx` - Receives `profile` prop
   250‚Üí
   251‚Üí**In Portfolio.tsx:**
   252‚Üí```tsx
   253‚Üíconst { profile } = useVariant();  // Get from context
   254‚Üí
   255‚Üí<HeroSection profile={profile} isMobile={isMobile} ... />
   256‚Üí<AboutSection profile={profile} isMobile={isMobile} ... />
   257‚Üí```
   258‚Üí
   259‚Üí### Routing
   260‚Üí
   261‚Üí**HashRouter** (GitHub Pages compatible):
   262‚Üí```tsx
   263‚Üí// src/App.tsx
   264‚Üí<HashRouter>
   265‚Üí  <Routes>
   266‚Üí    <Route path="/" element={<BasePortfolio />} />
   267‚Üí    <Route path="/:company/:role" element={<VariantPortfolio />} />
   268‚Üí  </Routes>
   269‚Üí</HashRouter>
   270‚Üí```
   271‚Üí
   272‚Üí**Why Hash Routing?**
   273‚Üí- GitHub Pages doesn't support server-side redirects
   274‚Üí- Hash URLs (`/#/company/role`) handled client-side
   275‚Üí- Fully shareable and bookmarkable
   276‚Üí- Can switch to BrowserRouter on Vercel/Netlify with proper config
   277‚Üí
   278‚Üí### Build Process
   279‚Üí
   280‚ÜíVariants are bundled as separate chunks for optimal loading:
   281‚Üí```
   282‚Üídist/assets/
   283‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bloomberg-technical-product-manager-[hash].js  (4KB)
   284‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ gensyn-technical-product-manager-[hash].js     (4KB)
   285‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ index-[hash].js                                (main bundle)
   286‚Üí```
   287‚Üí
   288‚ÜíVite's `import.meta.glob` enables lazy loading:
   289‚Üí```typescript
   290‚Üíconst variantFiles = import.meta.glob('../../content/variants/*.json', {
   291‚Üí  eager: false  // Lazy load only when needed
   292‚Üí});
   293‚Üí```
   294‚Üí
   295‚Üí---
   296‚Üí
   297‚Üí## Capstone Quality Pipeline (NEW)
   298‚Üí
   299‚ÜíThe capstone project wraps the Universal CV system with production-grade AI product evaluation.
   300‚Üí
   301‚Üí### Core Concept
   302‚Üí
   303‚Üí```
   304‚ÜíYAML is canonical ‚Üí JSON is derived
   305‚ÜíFacts live in knowledge base ‚Üí Variants reference them
   306‚ÜíEvery claim must be traceable ‚Üí Machine-checkable ledger
   307‚Üí```
   308‚Üí
   309‚Üí### Quality Scripts
   310‚Üí
   311‚Üí| Script | Purpose | Command |
   312‚Üí|--------|---------|---------|
   313‚Üí| `sync-variants.ts` | YAML‚ÜíJSON sync | `npm run variants:sync` |
   314‚Üí| `evaluate-variants.ts` | Generate claims ledger | `npm run eval:variant -- --slug <slug>` |
   315‚Üí| `redteam.ts` | Adversarial scanning | `npm run redteam:variant -- --slug <slug>` |
   316‚Üí
   317‚Üí### Build Integration
   318‚Üí
   319‚Üí```json
   320‚Üí"predev": "npm run variants:sync",
   321‚Üí"prebuild": "npm run validate && npm run variants:sync"
   322‚Üí```
   323‚Üí
   324‚ÜíEvery `npm run dev` and `npm run build` now enforces YAML/JSON parity.
   325‚Üí
   326‚Üí### Knowledge Base
   327‚Üí
   328‚Üí```
   329‚Üícontent/knowledge/
   330‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ index.yaml           # Entity graph
   331‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ achievements/        # STAR-format: Situation, Task, Action, Result
   332‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ankr-15x-revenue.yaml
   333‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ eth-staking-zero-slashing.yaml
   334‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...
   335‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ stories/             # Extended narratives
   336‚Üí```
   337‚Üí
   338‚Üí**Golden Rule**: Fix facts in the knowledge base, not in the variant output.
   339‚Üí
   340‚Üí### Claims Ledger
   341‚Üí
   342‚ÜíFor each variant, the evaluation script extracts metric-like claims and generates:
   343‚Üí- `capstone/develop/evals/<slug>.claims.yaml` ‚Äî Machine-checkable
   344‚Üí- `capstone/develop/evals/<slug>.eval.md` ‚Äî Human checklist
   345‚Üí
   346‚Üí```bash
   347‚Üínpm run eval:variant -- --slug bloomberg-technical-product-manager
   348‚Üínpm run eval:check  # Fails if unverified claims
   349‚Üí```
   350‚Üí
   351‚Üí### Red Team Checks
   352‚Üí
   353‚Üí| Check ID | Catches |
   354‚Üí|----------|---------|
   355‚Üí| `RT-SEC-SECRETS` | API keys, tokens |
   356‚Üí| `RT-SEC-CONFIDENTIAL` | NDA language |
   357‚Üí| `RT-TONE-SYCOPHANCY` | "thrilled", "dream company" |
   358‚Üí| `RT-ACC-INFLATION` | "about 15√ó" near metrics |
   359‚Üí| `RT-XVAR-CONTAM` | Mentions other target company |
   360‚Üí
   361‚Üí```bash
   362‚Üínpm run redteam:variant -- --slug bloomberg-technical-product-manager
   363‚Üínpm run redteam:check --strict  # WARN = FAIL
   364‚Üí```
   365‚Üí
   366‚Üí### PM Workflow
   367‚Üí
   368‚ÜíWork one variant at a time through the pipeline:
   369‚Üí1. `npm run variants:sync`
   370‚Üí2. `npm run eval:variant -- --slug <slug>`
   371‚Üí3. Verify claims in `*.claims.yaml`
   372‚Üí4. `npm run eval:check`
   373‚Üí5. `npm run redteam:variant -- --slug <slug>`
   374‚Üí6. `npm run redteam:check`
   375‚Üí7. Fix KB or variant wording until clean
   376‚Üí8. Commit + deploy
   377‚Üí

   379‚Üí
   380‚Üí## Design System
   381‚Üí
   382‚Üí### CSS Variables (globals.css)
   383‚Üí
   384‚Üí| Category | Examples |

     1‚Üí# Reorient ‚Äî ADHD-Aware Reality Check
     2‚Üí
     3‚Üí## When to Use This Skill
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíActivate when the user:
     6‚Üí- Says "reorient", "am I drifting?", "reality check", or "productive procrastination"
     7‚Üí- Has been working on something for a while without clear output
     8‚Üí- Is building tooling/infrastructure when they should be shipping
     9‚Üí- Seems excited about something tangential to their main goal
    10‚Üí- Asks "is this worth it?" or "should I keep going?"
    11‚Üí
    12‚Üí---
    13‚Üí
    14‚Üí## The Framework
    15‚Üí
    16‚Üí### Step 1: Ask Three Questions
    17‚Üí
    18‚ÜíAsk these directly, wait for answers:
    19‚Üí
    20‚Üí```
    21‚ÜíLet's do a quick reality check:
    22‚Üí
    23‚Üí1. **What's the actual goal?** (Job? Ship portfolio? Land interviews?)
    24‚Üí2. **What did you set out to do this session?**
    25‚Üí3. **What have you actually produced in the last hour?**
    26‚Üí```
    27‚Üí
    28‚Üí### Step 2: Identify the Gap
    29‚Üí
    30‚ÜíAfter they answer, assess:
    31‚Üí
    32‚Üí| Signal | Likely Status |
    33‚Üí|--------|---------------|
    34‚Üí| Clear goal + output matches | On track ‚Äî keep going |
    35‚Üí| Clear goal + output is tangential | Drifting ‚Äî redirect needed |
    36‚Üí| Vague goal + lots of "exploration" | Productive procrastination |
    37‚Üí| Building tools to build tools | Deep drift ‚Äî hard redirect |
    38‚Üí
    39‚Üí### Step 3: Give the Honest Feedback
    40‚Üí
    41‚Üí**If on track**: Acknowledge briefly and get out of the way.
    42‚Üí
    43‚Üí**If drifting**, use this format:
    44‚Üí
    45‚Üí```
    46‚Üí**Honest assessment**: You're [drifting/procrastinating].
    47‚Üí
    48‚ÜíWhat you're doing: [describe the activity]
    49‚ÜíWhat it feels like: [productive/interesting/important]
    50‚ÜíWhat it actually is: [avoiding the harder thing/premature optimization/scope creep]
    51‚Üí
    52‚ÜíThe thing you're avoiding is probably: [name it]
    53‚Üí```
    54‚Üí
    55‚Üí### Step 4: Redirect with One Action
    56‚Üí
    57‚ÜíGive exactly ONE concrete next action. Not a list. One thing.
    58‚Üí
    59‚Üí```
    60‚Üí**Do this next**: [single specific action]
    61‚Üí
    62‚ÜíDon't finish what you're doing. Don't "just clean this up first."
    63‚ÜíSwitch now. The thing you're working on will still be there.
    64‚Üí```
    65‚Üí
    66‚Üí---
    67‚Üí
    68‚Üí## ADHD-Specific Guidance
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí### Recognize the Patterns
    71‚Üí
    72‚Üí| Pattern | What It Looks Like | The Truth |
    73‚Üí|---------|-------------------|-----------|
    74‚Üí| **Tooling Rabbit Hole** | "I'll build a CLI to automate this" | The manual way takes 5 minutes |
    75‚Üí| **Perfect Setup** | "Let me organize everything first" | You're avoiding starting |
    76‚Üí| **Research Loop** | "I need to understand X before Y" | You already know enough |
    77‚Üí| **Scope Creep** | "While I'm here, I should also..." | Finish the first thing |
    78‚Üí| **Yak Shaving** | 4 levels deep in dependencies | Original task forgotten |
    79‚Üí
    80‚Üí### The Questions That Cut Through
    81‚Üí
    82‚Üí- "If you had to ship something in 30 minutes, what would it be?"
    83‚Üí- "What's the ONE thing that moves you closer to employed?"
    84‚Üí- "Is this thing you're building something a recruiter will ever see?"
    85‚Üí- "Are you building or are you preparing to build?"
    86‚Üí
    87‚Üí### Time-Boxing Reality
    88‚Üí
    89‚Üí```
    90‚ÜíIf the task feels like it needs "a few hours" ‚Üí It's probably scope creep
    91‚ÜíIf you've been "almost done" for 30+ minutes ‚Üí You're stuck, not finishing
    92‚ÜíIf you keep finding "one more thing" ‚Üí You're avoiding completion
    93‚Üí```
    94‚Üí
    95‚Üí---
    96‚Üí
    97‚Üí## Hard Truths to Deploy When Needed
    98‚Üí
    99‚ÜíUse these when gentle redirection isn't working:
   100‚Üí
   101‚Üí> "The portfolio doesn't need to be perfect. It needs to exist and be seen."
   102‚Üí
   103‚Üí> "No one will hire you because your internal tooling is elegant."
   104‚Üí
   105‚Üí> "Shipping something imperfect beats perfecting something unshipped."
   106‚Üí
   107‚Üí> "The best variant is the one you actually send to a real job posting."
   108‚Üí
   109‚Üí> "You're not procrastinating ‚Äî you're protecting yourself from rejection by never finishing."
   110‚Üí
   111‚Üí> "The CLI works. The pipeline works. What doesn't exist is a submitted application."
   112‚Üí
   113‚Üí---
   114‚Üí
   115‚Üí## Output Format
   116‚Üí
   117‚ÜíKeep it SHORT. ADHD brains bounce off walls of text.
   118‚Üí
   119‚Üí```
   120‚Üí## Reality Check
   121‚Üí
   122‚Üí**Goal**: [their stated goal]
   123‚Üí**Session intent**: [what they meant to do]
   124‚Üí**Actual output**: [what they produced]
   125‚Üí
   126‚Üí**Verdict**: [On track / Drifting / Procrastinating]
   127‚Üí
   128‚Üí[If drifting: 2-3 sentences max explaining the gap]
   129‚Üí
   130‚Üí**Do this now**: [ONE action]
   131‚Üí```
   132‚Üí
   133‚Üí---
   134‚Üí
   135‚Üí## Context Files to Reference
   136‚Üí
   137‚Üí| File | Why |
   138‚Üí|------|-----|
   139‚Üí| `context/PROJECT_STATE.md` | Current priorities and blockers |
   140‚Üí| Part II | Priority Action Plan ‚Äî what actually matters |
   141‚Üí| Part VI | Session Log ‚Äî what was supposed to happen |
   142‚Üí
   143‚Üí---
   144‚Üí
   145‚Üí## The Meta-Rule
   146‚Üí
   147‚ÜíIf the user is asking for a reality check, they probably already know they're drifting. The skill's job is to:
   148‚Üí
   149‚Üí1. Confirm the suspicion without judgment
   150‚Üí2. Name the avoidance behavior specifically
   151‚Üí3. Give ONE action to switch context
   152‚Üí4. Get out of the way
   153‚Üí
   154‚ÜíDon't lecture. Don't list 10 things. Don't be gentle to the point of enabling.
   155‚Üí
   156‚ÜíBe the friend who says "dude, you're doing it again" ‚Äî not the friend who says "that sounds really interesting, tell me more."
   157‚Üí

    47‚Üí
    48‚ÜíNo product-market fit meant the RPC product would get shut down or sold off. Team jobs were on the line.
    49‚Üí
    50‚Üí## The Challenge
    51‚Üí
    52‚ÜíAnkr's RPC infrastructure was underutilized and treated as a commodity. Competing on price with Infura and Alchemy in the developer segment was a race to the bottom. Needed differentiation and a sustainable business model.
    53‚Üí
    54‚ÜíThe constraints:
    55‚Üí- 5 engineers total
    56‚Üí- Infura and Alchemy owned developer mindshare
    57‚Üí- RPC is inherently commoditized‚Äîhard to differentiate on features
    58‚Üí- Developer segment has high churn and low willingness to pay
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí## The Approach
    61‚Üí
    62‚ÜíThe bet: blockchain protocols have different needs than individual developers. They need reliable infrastructure for their entire ecosystems, have longer sales cycles but higher LTV, and will pay premium for partnership-level support.
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üí### Alternatives Considered
    65‚Üí
    66‚Üí| Option | Trade-offs | Why Not |
    67‚Üí|--------|------------|---------|
    68‚Üí| Double down on developer DX | Large market, existing user base | Couldn't out-Alchemy Alchemy‚Äîthey had 10x our resources |
    69‚Üí| Pivot to enterprise (non-crypto) | Higher contract values | Sales cycle too long for our runway |
    70‚Üí| Build specialized APIs | Higher margins, less commoditized | Good complement but not standalone business |
    71‚Üí
    72‚ÜíWe pivoted to B2B protocol sales while building Advanced APIs as differentiation. Protocols became our core customer; developers became their users.
    73‚Üí
    74‚Üí## Key Decision
    75‚Üí
    76‚Üí**B2B pivot: protocols over developers**
    77‚Üí
    78‚ÜíTeam was attached to developer-first identity. Pivot felt like abandoning our roots.
    79‚Üí
    80‚ÜíShifted primary customer from developers to protocols. Developers became users we served through protocol partnerships.
    81‚Üí
    82‚Üí> Protocols had 10x LTV of developer accounts. One protocol deal = 100 developer signups in revenue. Unit economics finally worked.
    83‚Üí
    84‚Üí## Execution
    85‚Üí
    86‚Üí### Phase 1: Customer Discovery (4 weeks)
    87‚Üí- 15+ interviews with blockchain protocol teams about infrastructure pain points
    88‚Üí- Key insight: protocols were stitching together multiple providers
    89‚Üí- Mapped competitive landscape and pricing for protocol-tier contracts
    90‚Üí
    91‚Üí### Phase 2: Product Repositioning (3 weeks)
    92‚Üí- Pricing redesigned with protocol-tier and SLA guarantees
    93‚Üí- Partnership program with dedicated support channels
    94‚Üí- Case studies from early protocol conversations

    98‚Üí- Ankr.JS SDK for improved developer experience

    34‚Üí
    35‚ÜíRoyalty disputes with major publishers were costing millions in legal fees and damaging relationships. The $120B gaming industry needed a transparent system that could eliminate disputes and give publishers real-time visibility into their earnings.
    36‚Üí
    37‚Üí## The Challenge
    38‚Üí
    39‚ÜíXbox needed a transparent, auditable system for tracking and distributing royalty payments to game publishers. Existing databases couldn't give publishers the auditability they demanded‚Äîand disputes over payment accuracy were getting expensive.
    40‚Üí
    41‚ÜíThe constraints:
    42‚Üí- Xbox-scale transaction volumes (millions of purchases)
    43‚Üí- Publishers need real-time visibility into royalty accruals
    44‚Üí- Audit trail must be immutable and independently verifiable
    45‚Üí- Transaction data can't be exposed to competitors
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí## The Approach
    48‚Üí
    49‚ÜíThe bet: blockchain gives publishers the immutability and transparency they need, while smart contracts automate complex royalty calculations that were error-prone when done manually.
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí### Alternatives Considered
    52‚Üí
    53‚Üí| Option | Trade-offs | Why Not |
    54‚Üí|--------|------------|---------|
    55‚Üí| Enhanced database with audit logging | Simpler, existing infrastructure | Publishers didn't trust Microsoft-controlled audit logs |
    56‚Üí| Public Ethereum mainnet | Maximum transparency, decentralization | Transaction data couldn't be public‚Äîcompetitor intelligence risk. Gas costs prohibitive |
    57‚Üí| Hyperledger | Enterprise-ready, permissioned by design | Wanted Ethereum ecosystem for tooling and talent |
    58‚Üí
    59‚ÜíWe went with a private Ethereum consortium‚Äîpermissioned access, Ethereum compatibility for tooling, transaction privacy preserved.
    60‚Üí
    61‚Üí## Key Decision
    62‚Üí
    63‚Üí**Private consortium vs. public Ethereum**
    64‚Üí
    65‚ÜíSome stakeholders pushed for public chain for "true decentralization." Publishers were concerned about data exposure.
    66‚Üí
    67‚ÜíChose private consortium. Gave publishers what they actually needed (independent verification) without exposing competitive data.
    68‚Üí
    69‚Üí> This pattern became the template for other Microsoft blockchain projects.
    70‚Üí
    71‚Üí## Execution
    72‚Üí
    73‚Üí### Phase 1: Proof of Concept (3 months)
    74‚Üí- Initial smart contract for basic royalty calculation logic
    75‚Üí- Demonstrated to Xbox leadership that blockchain could handle required throughput
    76‚Üí- Identified key technical risks: key management, network consensus, data privacy
    77‚Üí
    78‚Üí### Phase 2: Infrastructure Build (6 months)
    79‚Üí- Docker/Kubernetes architecture for blockchain consortium nodes
    80‚Üí- Deployment automation for multi-node Ethereum network on Azure

     1‚Üí---
     2‚Üítitle: "Building a Universal CV Engine"
     3‚Üídate: "2024-12-22"
     4‚Üíexcerpt: "How a career transition led to building an AI-powered portfolio system‚Äîcombining Web3 experience, an AI PM certification capstone, and a lot of late nights."
     5‚Üítags: ["Career", "AI", "Portfolio", "Capstone"]
     6‚Üíthumbnail: null
     7‚Üí---
     8‚Üí
     9‚ÜíFound myself between roles. Sat with the question everyone asks: *what's next?*
    10‚Üí
    11‚ÜíI knew two things: I wanted to stay at the intersection of Web3 and AI, and I needed a better way to present my work. The standard resume wasn't cutting it. LinkedIn felt like shouting into the void.
    12‚Üí
    13‚ÜíSo I started building.
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí## From Resume to Portfolio
    16‚Üí
    17‚ÜíFirst version was just a static page. More resume than portfolio‚Äîbullet points, job titles, the usual. It worked, but it didn't *differentiate*.
    18‚Üí
    19‚ÜíI needed a brand. Something that captured what I actually do: build trust infrastructure at the edge of new technology. "Edge of Trust" stuck.
    20‚Üí
    21‚ÜíThe portfolio evolved. Case studies instead of bullet points. Real metrics instead of vague impact claims. A design system that didn't look like every other developer portfolio.
    22‚Üí
    23‚ÜíBut I wanted more.
    24‚Üí
    25‚Üí## The Capstone Connection
    26‚Üí
    27‚ÜíWhile building the portfolio, I was taking the [AI Product Management Certification](https://maven.com/product-faculty/ai-product-management-certification) from Product Faculty. The course teaches a 4D approach to building AI features: Discover, Define, Develop, Deliver.
    28‚Üí
    29‚ÜíThe certification requires a capstone project. Most people build something separate. I thought: why not combine them?
    30‚Üí
    31‚ÜíWhat if the portfolio itself was the capstone? What if I built an AI-powered system that could generate targeted portfolio variants for specific job applications?
    32‚Üí
    33‚ÜíThat's how Universal CV was born.
    34‚Üí
    35‚Üí## What Universal CV Actually Is
    36‚Üí
    37‚ÜíThe core idea is simple: create targeted portfolio pages that are accurate without embellishment, tailored to specific roles based on my actual experience data and the job description I'm applying for.
    38‚Üí
    39‚ÜíThe system has three parts:
    40‚Üí
    41‚Üí**1. Knowledge Base**
    42‚ÜíAll my achievements, metrics, and stories stored in structured YAML. Every claim traceable to a source. No hallucination possible because the AI can only surface what's already documented.
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí**2. Variant Engine**
    45‚ÜíTakes a job description, matches it against my knowledge base, and generates a customized portfolio variant. Different emphasis for different roles‚Äîinfrastructure PM vs. developer tools PM vs. Web3 PM.
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí**3. Quality Pipeline**
    48‚ÜíThis is where it gets interesting. I built an eval and red-teaming harness:
    49‚Üí
    50‚Üí```
    51‚ÜíKnowledge Base ‚Üí Variant YAML ‚Üí Sync ‚Üí Eval ‚Üí Red Team ‚Üí Deploy
    52‚Üí```
    53‚Üí
    54‚ÜíThe eval step extracts every claim and finds candidate sources. The red team step scans for:
    55‚Üí- Sycophantic language ("thrilled to apply")
    56‚Üí- Unverified metrics
    57‚Üí- Cross-variant contamination (mentioning wrong company)
    58‚Üí- Confidential information leaks
    59‚Üí
    60‚ÜíIf a variant doesn't pass the gates, it doesn't ship.
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí## Why This Matters
    63‚Üí
    64‚ÜíMost AI-generated content has a trust problem. It sounds plausible but might be fabricated. For a portfolio‚Äîwhere your professional reputation is on the line‚Äîthat's unacceptable.
    65‚Üí
    66‚ÜíUniversal CV inverts the approach. Instead of generating content and hoping it's accurate, it:
    67‚Üí1. Starts with verified source data
    68‚Üí2. Constrains generation to that data
    69‚Üí3. Evaluates every claim against sources
    70‚Üí4. Red-teams for tone and accuracy issues
    71‚Üí
    72‚ÜíThe AI assists with targeting and presentation. The facts come from me.
    73‚Üí
    74‚Üí## What I've Built So Far
    75‚Üí
    76‚Üí- Portfolio site with 4 case studies, 3 blog posts, full design system
    77‚Üí- Variant engine supporting 5 targeted variants
    78‚Üí- Claims evaluation pipeline with source matching
    79‚Üí- Red team scanner with 8+ automated checks
    80‚Üí- Interactive CLI dashboard (`npm run ucv-cli`) for managing the whole flow
    81‚Üí
    82‚Üí## What's Next
    83‚Üí
    84‚ÜíStill working on the evaluation flow. The harness is built, but I want to run proper experiments:
    85‚Üí- How well does variant targeting match JD requirements?
    86‚Üí- What's the false negative rate on the red team checks?
    87‚Üí- Can I automate more of the claim verification?
    88‚Üí
    89‚ÜíGoal is to open-source this once the capstone is complete. Job searching sucks. Maybe this helps someone else.
    90‚Üí
    91‚Üí## The Real Outcome
    92‚Üí
    93‚ÜíAt the end of this, I'll have:
    94‚Üí
    95‚Üí1. **A professional-grade portfolio** ‚Äî Not a template, a system
    96‚Üí2. **Universal CV engine** ‚Äî AI-powered variant generation with quality gates
    97‚Üí3. **Deep understanding of AI evaluation** ‚Äî Not just theory, hands-on implementation
    98‚Üí
    99‚ÜíCareer transitions create space. This one let me build something I wouldn't have built otherwise.

     1‚Üí# Universal CV System - Complete Guide
     2‚Üí
     3‚Üí## Overview
     4‚Üí
     5‚ÜíThe Universal CV system allows you to create personalized portfolio variants tailored to specific job applications. Each variant customizes your hero section, bio, stats, and content emphasis while maintaining factual accuracy.
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí## Live Examples
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí- **Base Portfolio**: `https://edgeoftrust.com/#/`
    10‚Üí- **Bloomberg (TPM)**: `https://edgeoftrust.com/#/bloomberg/technical-product-manager`
    11‚Üí- **Gensyn (TPM)**: `https://edgeoftrust.com/#/gensyn/technical-product-manager`
    12‚Üí
    13‚Üí---
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí## Architecture
    16‚Üí
    17‚Üí### URL Structure
    18‚Üí```
    19‚Üí/#/:company/:role
    20‚Üí```
    21‚Üí
    22‚ÜíExamples:
    23‚Üí- `/#/bloomberg/technical-product-manager`
    24‚Üí- `/#/stripe/senior-pm`
    25‚Üí- `/#/databricks/ml-platform-lead`
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí### Data Flow
    28‚Üí
    29‚Üí```
    30‚Üí1. User visits /#/bloomberg/technical-product-manager
    31‚Üí2. React Router captures params: { company: "bloomberg", role: "technical-product-manager" }
    32‚Üí3. VariantPortfolio loads variant JSON: bloomberg-technical-product-manager.json
    33‚Üí4. mergeProfile() combines base profile + variant overrides
    34‚Üí5. VariantContext provides merged profile to Portfolio component
    35‚Üí6. Sections render personalized content
    36‚Üí```
    37‚Üí
    38‚Üí### File Structure
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí```
    41‚Üícontent/variants/
    42‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md                                    # Variant documentation
    43‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ _template.yaml                               # Template for new variants
    44‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bloomberg-technical-product-manager.yaml     # Human-readable source
    45‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ bloomberg-technical-product-manager.json     # Client-side loading
    46‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ gensyn-technical-product-manager.yaml
    47‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ gensyn-technical-product-manager.json
    48‚Üí```
    49‚Üí
    50‚Üí---
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí## Creating a New Variant
    53‚Üí
    54‚Üí### Method 1: CLI Generator (Recommended)
    55‚Üí
    56‚Üí```bash
    57‚Üí# Set API key
    58‚Üíexport GEMINI_API_KEY=your_key_here
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí# Generate variant
    61‚Üínpm run generate:cv -- \
    62‚Üí  --company "Stripe" \
    63‚Üí  --role "Senior PM" \
    64‚Üí  --jd "./stripe-jd.txt" \
    65‚Üí  --provider gemini
    66‚Üí
    67‚Üí# Or inline job description
    68‚Üínpm run generate:cv -- \
    69‚Üí  --company "Databricks" \
    70‚Üí  --role "ML Platform Lead" \
    71‚Üí  --jd-text "Job description here..." \
    72‚Üí  --provider gemini
    73‚Üí```
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí**CLI Options:**
    76‚Üí- `--company <name>` - Company name (required)
    77‚Üí- `--role <title>` - Role title (required)
    78‚Üí- `--jd <file>` - Path to job description file
    79‚Üí- `--jd-text <text>` - Job description as inline text
    80‚Üí- `--values <text>` - Company values (optional)

     1‚Üí# Capstone Quality Pipeline: Step-by-Step Workflow
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíThis guide walks you through the complete quality pipeline for a variant, using `mysten-walrus-senior-pm` as a working example.
     4‚Üí
     5‚Üí---
     6‚Üí
     7‚Üí## Quick Reference: File Locations
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí| What | Where | Purpose |
    10‚Üí|------|-------|---------|
    11‚Üí| **Variant YAML** | `content/variants/<slug>.yaml` | Source of truth (edit this) |
    12‚Üí| **Variant JSON** | `content/variants/<slug>.json` | Runtime artifact (auto-generated) |
    13‚Üí| **Knowledge Base** | `content/knowledge/achievements/*.yaml` | Facts & metrics source |
    14‚Üí| **Claims Ledger** | `capstone/develop/evals/<slug>.claims.yaml` | Extracted claims + verification status |
    15‚Üí| **Eval Checklist** | `capstone/develop/evals/<slug>.eval.md` | Human-readable checklist |
    16‚Üí| **Red Team Report** | `capstone/develop/redteam/<slug>.redteam.md` | Adversarial scan results |
    17‚Üí| **Evaluation Rubric** | `capstone/develop/evaluation.md` | How claims are evaluated |
    18‚Üí| **Threat Model** | `capstone/develop/red-teaming.md` | Red team check definitions |
    19‚Üí
    20‚Üí---
    21‚Üí
    22‚Üí## The Pipeline Flow
    23‚Üí
    24‚Üí```
    25‚Üí‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê
    26‚Üí‚îÇ  1. SYNC          2. EVALUATE         3. RED TEAM         4. SHIP          ‚îÇ
    27‚Üí‚îÇ                                                                             ‚îÇ
    28‚Üí‚îÇ  YAML ‚Üí JSON      Extract claims      Adversarial         Deploy if        ‚îÇ
    29‚Üí‚îÇ  (deterministic)  Find sources        scans               gates pass       ‚îÇ
    30‚Üí‚îÇ                   Mark verified                                             ‚îÇ
    31‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
    32‚Üí```
    33‚Üí
    34‚Üí---
    35‚Üí
    36‚Üí## Step 1: Sync Variants
    37‚Üí
    38‚Üí**Purpose**: Convert YAML (human-editable) to JSON (runtime artifact).
    39‚Üí

     1‚Üí# Content Management Guide
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíComplete guide for managing content in the portfolio.
     4‚Üí
     5‚Üí## Overview
     6‚Üí
     7‚ÜíThe portfolio uses a **file-based content system** with:
     8‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Auto-discovery** - Drop files and they appear
     9‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Type safety** - Zod validation catches errors
    10‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Hot reload** - See changes instantly in development
    11‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Templates** - Copy-paste starter files
    12‚Üí
    13‚Üí## Content Types
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí| Type | Location | Format | Auto-discovered |
    16‚Üí|------|----------|--------|-----------------|
    17‚Üí| Case Studies | `content/case-studies/` | Markdown + YAML | Yes |
    18‚Üí| Passion Projects | `content/passion-projects/index.yaml` | YAML array | No |
    19‚Üí| Blog Posts | `content/blog/` | Markdown + YAML | Yes |
    20‚Üí| Profile | `content/profile.yaml` | YAML | No |
    21‚Üí| Experience | `content/experience/index.yaml` | YAML | No |
    22‚Üí| Testimonials | `content/testimonials/index.yaml` | YAML | No |
    23‚Üí| Certifications | `content/certifications/index.yaml` | YAML | No |
    24‚Üí
    25‚Üí---
    26‚Üí
    27‚Üí## Adding New Content
    28‚Üí
    29‚Üí### Case Study
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí1. **Copy template:**
    32‚Üí```bash
    33‚Üícp content/_templates/case-study.md content/case-studies/05-my-project.md
    34‚Üí```
    35‚Üí
    36‚Üí2. **Edit frontmatter:**
    37‚Üí   - Update `id` (next available: 5, 6, 7...)
    38‚Üí   - Set unique `slug`
    39‚Üí   - Fill all required fields
    40‚Üí   - Remove optional fields you don't need
    41‚Üí
    42‚Üí3. **Write content:**
    43‚Üí   - Use markdown below the `---` delimiter
    44‚Üí   - Follow existing structure
    45‚Üí   - Include metrics, decisions, learnings
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí4. **Validate:**
    48‚Üí```bash
    49‚Üínpm run validate
    50‚Üí```
    51‚Üí
    52‚Üí5. **Preview:**
    53‚Üí```bash
    54‚Üínpm run dev
    55‚Üí# Visit http://localhost:5173
    56‚Üí```
    57‚Üí
    58‚Üí**File naming:** `NN-slug.md` where NN is the ID padded with zeros
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí---
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí### Passion Project
    63‚Üí
    64‚Üí1. **Copy template entry:**
    65‚Üí```bash
    66‚Üícat content/_templates/passion-project-entry.yaml
    67‚Üí```
    68‚Üí
    69‚Üí2. **Edit `content/passion-projects/index.yaml`:**
    70‚Üí   - Add new entry to `projects` array
    71‚Üí   - Update `id` (next number in sequence)
    72‚Üí   - Fill required fields
    73‚Üí   - Set URLs to `null` if not applicable
    74‚Üí
    75‚Üí3. **Validate:**
    76‚Üí```bash
    77‚Üínpm run validate
    78‚Üí```
    79‚Üí

     8‚Üí
     9‚ÜíFound myself between roles. Sat with the question everyone asks: *what's next?*
    10‚Üí
    11‚ÜíI knew two things: I wanted to stay at the intersection of Web3 and AI, and I needed a better way to present my work. The standard resume wasn't cutting it. LinkedIn felt like shouting into the void.
    12‚Üí
    13‚ÜíSo I started building.
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí## From Resume to Portfolio
    16‚Üí
    17‚ÜíFirst version was just a static page. More resume than portfolio‚Äîbullet points, job titles, the usual. It worked, but it didn't *differentiate*.
    18‚Üí
    19‚ÜíI needed a brand. Something that captured what I actually do: build trust infrastructure at the edge of new technology. "Edge of Trust" stuck.
    20‚Üí
    21‚ÜíThe portfolio evolved. Case studies instead of bullet points. Real metrics instead of vague impact claims. A design system that didn't look like every other developer portfolio.
    22‚Üí
    23‚ÜíBut I wanted more.
    24‚Üí
    25‚Üí## The Capstone Connection
    26‚Üí
    27‚ÜíWhile building the portfolio, I was taking the [AI Product Management Certification](https://maven.com/product-faculty/ai-product-management-certification) from Product Faculty. The course teaches a 4D approach to building AI features: Discover, Define, Develop, Deliver.
    28‚Üí
    29‚ÜíThe certification requires a capstone project. Most people build something separate. I thought: why not combine them?
    30‚Üí
    31‚ÜíWhat if the portfolio itself was the capstone? What if I built an AI-powered system that could generate targeted portfolio variants for specific job applications?
    32‚Üí
    33‚ÜíThat's how Universal CV was born.
    34‚Üí
    35‚Üí## What Universal CV Actually Is
    36‚Üí
    37‚ÜíThe core idea is simple: create targeted portfolio pages that are accurate without embellishment, tailored to specific roles based on my actual experience data and the job description I'm applying for.
    38‚Üí
    39‚ÜíThe system has three parts:
    40‚Üí
    41‚Üí**1. Knowledge Base**
    42‚ÜíAll my achievements, metrics, and stories stored in structured YAML. Every claim traceable to a source. No hallucination possible because the AI can only surface what's already documented.
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí**2. Variant Engine**
    45‚ÜíTakes a job description, matches it against my knowledge base, and generates a customized portfolio variant. Different emphasis for different roles‚Äîinfrastructure PM vs. developer tools PM vs. Web3 PM.
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí**3. Quality Pipeline**
    48‚ÜíThis is where it gets interesting. I built an eval and red-teaming harness:
    49‚Üí
    50‚Üí```
    51‚ÜíKnowledge Base ‚Üí Variant YAML ‚Üí Sync ‚Üí Eval ‚Üí Red Team ‚Üí Deploy
    52‚Üí```
    53‚Üí
    54‚ÜíThe eval step extracts every claim and finds candidate sources. The red team step scans for:
    55‚Üí- Sycophantic language ("thrilled to apply")
    56‚Üí- Unverified metrics
    57‚Üí- Cross-variant contamination (mentioning wrong company)
    58‚Üí- Confidential information leaks
    59‚Üí
    60‚ÜíIf a variant doesn't pass the gates, it doesn't ship.
    61‚Üí
    62‚Üí## Why This Matters
    63‚Üí
    64‚ÜíMost AI-generated content has a trust problem. It sounds plausible but might be fabricated. For a portfolio‚Äîwhere your professional reputation is on the line‚Äîthat's unacceptable.
    65‚Üí
    66‚ÜíUniversal CV inverts the approach. Instead of generating content and hoping it's accurate, it:
    67‚Üí1. Starts with verified source data
    68‚Üí2. Constrains generation to that data
    69‚Üí3. Evaluates every claim against sources
    70‚Üí4. Red-teams for tone and accuracy issues
    71‚Üí
    72‚ÜíThe AI assists with targeting and presentation. The facts come from me.
    73‚Üí
    74‚Üí## What I've Built So Far
    75‚Üí
    76‚Üí- Portfolio site with 4 case studies, 3 blog posts, full design system
    77‚Üí- Variant engine supporting 5 targeted variants
    78‚Üí- Claims evaluation pipeline with source matching
    79‚Üí- Red team scanner with 8+ automated checks
    80‚Üí- Interactive CLI dashboard (`npm run ucv-cli`) for managing the whole flow
    81‚Üí
    82‚Üí## What's Next
    83‚Üí
    84‚ÜíStill working on the evaluation flow. The harness is built, but I want to run proper experiments:
    85‚Üí- How well does variant targeting match JD requirements?
    86‚Üí- What's the false negative rate on the red team checks?
    87‚Üí- Can I automate more of the claim verification?
    88‚Üí
    89‚ÜíGoal is to open-source this once the capstone is complete. Job searching sucks. Maybe this helps someone else.
    90‚Üí
    91‚Üí## The Real Outcome
    92‚Üí
    93‚ÜíAt the end of this, I'll have:
    94‚Üí
    95‚Üí1. **A professional-grade portfolio** ‚Äî Not a template, a system
    96‚Üí2. **Universal CV engine** ‚Äî AI-powered variant generation with quality gates

    10‚Üí
    11‚Üí## The Problem with Manual Validation
    12‚Üí
    13‚ÜíWhen you're managing a portfolio with multiple content types (case studies, blog posts, projects), manual checking doesn't scale:
    14‚Üí
    15‚Üí**Common mistakes:**
    16‚Üí- Typos in YAML keys (`compnay` instead of `company`)
    17‚Üí- Wrong date formats (`12/15/2024` vs. `2024-12-15`)
    18‚Üí- Missing required fields that crash builds
    19‚Üí- Duplicate IDs between case studies
    20‚Üí- Invalid URLs that go unnoticed
    21‚Üí
    22‚ÜíThese errors often don't surface until:
    23‚Üí1. Your build fails in CI/CD
    24‚Üí2. A recruiter clicks a broken link
    25‚Üí3. Your case study drawer shows `undefined`
    26‚Üí
    27‚ÜíBy then, it's too late.
    28‚Üí
    29‚Üí## The Solution: Schema Validation
    30‚Üí
    31‚ÜíThe answer is **Zod schemas** combined with a validation CLI.
    32‚Üí
    33‚Üí### What This Looks Like
    34‚Üí
    35‚Üí```typescript
    36‚Üí// Define your schema once
    37‚Üíconst CaseStudySchema = z.object({
    38‚Üí  id: z.number(),
    39‚Üí  title: z.string(),
    40‚Üí  year: z.string(),
    41‚Üí  // ... all your fields
    42‚Üí});
    43‚Üí
    44‚Üí// Validate before commit
    45‚ÜívalidateFile(caseStudy, CaseStudySchema);
    46‚Üí```
    47‚Üí
    48‚Üí### Benefits
    49‚Üí
    50‚Üí1. **Catch errors early** - Before they reach production
    51‚Üí2. **Self-documenting** - Schema is your source of truth
    52‚Üí3. **Type safety** - TypeScript types derived from schemas
    53‚Üí4. **Fast feedback** - Run validation in <1 second
    54‚Üí5. **CI/CD integration** - Block bad commits automatically
    55‚Üí
    56‚Üí## Real-World Example
    57‚Üí
    58‚ÜíHere's what validation caught in my portfolio:
    59‚Üí
    60‚Üí```bash
    61‚Üínpm run validate
    62‚Üí
    63‚Üí‚úó Case Study: 05-new-project.md
    64‚Üí  ‚úó hook.impactMetric.value: Required
    65‚Üí  ‚úó year: Expected YYYY or YYYY-YY format
    66‚Üí  ‚úó cta.action: Invalid enum value
    67‚Üí```

    74‚Üí```typescript

    76‚Üí  id: z.number(),

    78‚Üí  title: z.string(),
    79‚Üí  company: z.string(),
    80‚Üí  year: z.string(),

```md
---
title: "Building a Portfolio That Proves Itself"
date: "2024-12-22"
excerpt: "The best portfolio isn't one that looks good‚Äîit's one where every claim traces to proof. Here's what I learned building a system that verifies itself."
tags: ["Career", "AI", "Portfolio", "Capstone", "Web3"]
thumbnail: null
---

Found myself between roles. Sat with the question everyone asks: *what's next?*

I knew two things: I wanted to stay at the intersection of Web3 and AI, and I needed a better way to present my work. The standard resume wasn't cutting it. LinkedIn felt like shouting into the void.

So I started building. Three months later, I had something unexpected: not just a portfolio, but a system that proves its own claims.

## The Problem

Generic portfolios don't convert. Every product manager has "drove growth" and "led cross-functional teams" on their resume. Metrics help, but metrics without sources feel hollow. How do you know those numbers are real?

And here's the real problem: when you're applying for multiple roles, you need different emphasis. The infrastructure PM variant isn't the Web3 PM variant isn't the developer tools PM variant. Maintaining multiple versions by hand is a nightmare.

I wanted something that could generate targeted variants while ensuring every claim was defensible.

## What I Built

The system has four layers:

**Knowledge Base**: Every achievement lives in structured YAML, using STAR format (Situation, Task, Action, Result). Each metric traces to a source. No hallucination possible‚Äîthe AI can only surface what's already documented.

**Variant Engine**: Takes a job description, matches it against my knowledge base, scores relevance, and generates a customized portfolio. Different stats, different case study ordering, same underlying facts.

**Quality Pipeline**: This is where it gets interesting. Every variant runs through:
- **Eval**: Extracts claims, finds candidate sources, verifies each metric
- **Red Team**: Scans for sycophantic language, unverified metrics, cross-variant contamination, confidential leaks

**Skills Ecosystem**: Nine Claude Code skills that codify the workflow. The AI doesn't freelance‚Äîit follows documented patterns with human approval gates.

## The Numbers

What three months of building produced:

| Metric | Value |
|--------|-------|
| CSS Variables | 124 (full design system) |
| Initial Bundle | 195KB gzip (59% reduction from 480KB) |
| Claude Code Skills | 9 (knowledge ‚Üí content ‚Üí variants) |
| Job-Specific Variants | 9 active |
| Claims Per Variant | ~6 (100% traceable) |
| Red Team Checks | 8 automated gates |
| Tests | 211 passing |

## What I Learned

### Tier 1: Fundamental Shifts

**Schema is law.** Zod validates everything. A typo in a YAML field doesn't silently fail‚Äîit blocks the build. Content quality compounds when you enforce it at the source.

**Voice is brand.** I created a separate skill just for writing style. Not embedded in generators‚Äîexplicit and mandatory. Same facts rendered in consistent voice across every variant, email, and document.

**Verification beats trust.** Every metric in a variant traces to a knowledge base file. If the source changes, the variant fails eval. You can't accidentally ship unverified claims.

### Tier 2: Architectural Decisions

**YAML for humans, JSON for machines.** Variants live in YAML (human-reviewable), sync to JSON (runtime artifact). One canonical source, derived outputs. No drift.

**Code splitting saved 59%.** The bundle hit 480KB and I stopped everything to fix it. Lazy-loaded routes, vendor chunking, component-level splitting. Target was under 200KB‚Äîhit 195KB.

**CSS variables over CSS-in-JS.** Theme switching is instant‚Äîno React re-render needed. 124 variables covering color, spacing, layout, effects. Dark and light mode parity without JavaScript overhead.

### Tier 3: Process Insights

**Pause between phases.** The variant skill has explicit approval gates: show content ‚Üí user approves ‚Üí run eval ‚Üí user reviews ‚Üí red team ‚Üí user approves ‚Üí ship. No autonomous hallucination.

**Existing connections are gold.** When generating the Galaxy variant, I discovered they were already an Anchorage client (from ETH staking work). Lead with what you've already proven.

**Stats should be punchy.** "8+" beats "approximately eight." "Zero" beats "no instances of." "40%" beats "significant improvement." Every stat verifiable, every stat memorable.

### Tier 4: Meta Learnings

**ADHD patterns are predictable.** I built a skill that diagnoses drift: tooling rabbit holes, perfect setup syndrome, research loops, scope creep. The system catches me when I'm avoiding the real work.

**Multi-perspective briefings work.** Sprint sync outputs from four angles: PM (priorities), Designer (system health), Architect (dependencies), Engineer (recent changes). Different lenses, same project.

**The last 8% is applying.** The portfolio is 92% done. The remaining 8% isn't code‚Äîit's hitting submit on applications. Portfolio perfection is a form of procrastination.

## The Pipeline in Practice

Here's what generating a variant actually looks like:

\```bash
# Phase 1: Job analysis
# Extract requirements, generate slug, check for existing variants

# Phase 2: Knowledge base query
npm run cv-knowledge-query -- --theme "institutional-crypto"

# Phase 3: Content generation (with writing style skill)
# Generate hero, about, stats‚Äîall from verified sources

# Phase 4: Sync and validate
npm run variants:sync -- --slug microsoft-senior-pm

# Phase 5: Evaluate claims
npm run eval:variant -- --slug microsoft-senior-pm
# Output: 6/6 claims verified

# Phase 6: Red team
npm run redteam:variant -- --slug microsoft-senior-pm
# Output: 0 FAIL, 0 WARN

# Phase 7: Visual review
open "http://localhost:5173/microsoft/senior-pm"
\```

The whole flow takes about 15 minutes. Most of that is human review, not generation.

## Why This Matters

Most AI-generated content has a trust problem. It sounds plausible but might be fabricated. For a portfolio‚Äîwhere your professional reputation is on the line‚Äîthat's unacceptable.

This system inverts the approach:
1. Start with verified source data
2. Constrain generation to that data
3. Evaluate every claim against sources
4. Red-team for tone and accuracy issues
5. Require human approval at each gate

The AI assists with targeting and presentation. The facts come from documented achievements.

## What's Next

The portfolio is live. The capstone is submitted. But the work continues:

- **More variants**: Galaxy, Microsoft, Coinbase, Gensyn all in active rotation
- **Case studies**: Documenting the portfolio build itself, the Universal CV pipeline, the AI-assisted job search
- **Open source**: Planning to release the variant generation system once it's battle-tested

## The Real Lesson

Career transitions create space. This one let me build something I wouldn't have built otherwise‚Äîa portfolio that doesn't just show my work, but demonstrates the rigor I bring to shipping.

Every claim traceable. Every variant verified. Every stat defensible in an interview.

That's the portfolio I wanted. That's the portfolio I built.

---

*The portfolio is live at [dmitriif.eth](https://dmitriif.eth.limo). The capstone is complete. If you're building in the AI evaluation space or just want to see the variant system in action, [reach out](https://calendly.com/dmitrii-f).*

```

# Portfolio Project: Learnings Inventory

**Created**: 2024-12-22
**Purpose**: Ranked list of learnings from portfolio build, each with a potential blog post angle.

---

## Tier 1: High Impact ‚Äî Write These First

These are fundamental shifts that apply beyond this project.

| # | Learning | Blog Post Idea | Angle |
|---|----------|----------------|-------|
| 1 | **Claims verification system** | "Why Every Portfolio Metric Needs a Source" | The trust problem in AI-generated content. How claims extraction + source matching creates accountability. |
| 2 | **Writing style as separate skill** | "Your Voice is Your Brand: Codifying Writing Style" | Voice consistency across AI-generated content. Why style should be explicit, not embedded. |
| 3 | **Schema-first content** | "Zod as Content Gatekeeper" | Schema validation as quality infrastructure. Content errors caught at build time, not production. |

**Why Tier 1**: These learnings change how you think about content generation, not just how you implement it.

---

## Tier 2: Medium Impact ‚Äî Strong Standalone Posts

These are solid technical narratives with clear before/after.

| # | Learning | Blog Post Idea | Angle |
|---|----------|----------------|-------|
| 4 | **Code splitting journey** | "480KB ‚Üí 195KB: A React Bundle Diet" | The moment bundle size became P0. Lazy routes, vendor chunks, component splitting. 59% reduction. |
| 5 | **Variant generation workflow** | "One Portfolio, N Applications: The Universal CV" | Job-specific positioning without maintaining N separate files. Knowledge base ‚Üí variant ‚Üí eval ‚Üí ship. |
| 6 | **Red teaming your own content** | "Adversarial Testing for Portfolio Integrity" | 8 automated checks. Sycophancy detection, secret scanning, cross-variant contamination. |
| 7 | **YAML ‚Üí JSON architecture** | "Human-Editable, Machine-Consumable: Content Architecture" | Canonical source in YAML, derived artifacts in JSON. One source of truth, multiple consumers. |

**Why Tier 2**: Technical depth with measurable outcomes. Good for developer audiences.

---

## Tier 3: Niche ‚Äî Valuable but Specific

These are interesting but may not resonate broadly.

| # | Learning | Blog Post Idea | Angle |
|---|----------|----------------|-------|
| 8 | **CSS variables for theming** | "Why I Chose CSS Variables Over styled-components" | 124 variables, instant theme switching, no JavaScript overhead. Trade-offs vs CSS-in-JS. |
| 9 | **ADHD-aware AI skills** | "Building AI Tools for Brains That Drift" | The `reorient` skill. Diagnosing tooling rabbit holes, perfect setup syndrome, scope creep. Hard truths that help. |
| 10 | **Multi-perspective briefings** | "Sprint Sync: PM, Designer, Architect, Engineer Views" | One project, four lenses. How different perspectives catch different issues. |
| 11 | **Phased execution with gates** | "Stop, Review, Proceed: Why AI Needs Approval Gates" | The pause points in variant generation. Human oversight prevents hallucination. |
| 12 | **Existing connections as leverage** | "Lead With Proof: Finding Hidden Connections" | Galaxy was already an Anchorage client. Mining your own history for positioning gold. |

**Why Tier 3**: Specific techniques that worked for this project. May not generalize.

---

## Case Study Queue

Separate from blog posts‚Äîdeeper narratives with full project context.

| Priority | Case Study | Scope | Audience |
|----------|------------|-------|----------|
| 1 | **Portfolio Engineering** | Full build: design system, code splitting, variant system, testing | Technical PMs, engineering managers |
| 2 | **Universal CV Pipeline** | YAML‚ÜíJSON‚Üíeval‚Üíredteam flow. Claims verification in depth. | AI product folks, content systems builders |
| 3 | **AI-Assisted Job Search** | Meta-story: using Claude Code for career transition | Career transitioners, AI curious |

---
